story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsPoldy Van Lynden has crossed Loch Fyne and back again for a good cause.As reported in last week#s edition, Poldy took on the swimming challenge to raise much-needed funds for Tighnabruaich RNLI which, in common with many other charities, has taken a funding hit during lockdown.The idea was for Poldy to swim across Loch Fyne from Otter Ferry to the western shore near Achnaba # something he says he had wanted to do for a couple of years.On Saturday June  he succeeded and said afterwards: #The weather just about held, although thejourney was tough with the wind and the tide. I made it in about two-and-a half hours.#Poldy added: #I#m so grateful for the amount of support from locals, friends and family. I find it particularly touching to see donations from people I don#t know so well or friends I haven#t spoken to in a long time.#Earlier this week, the total raised for Tighnabruaich leboat stood at £,.To support Poldy#s efforts, visit www.virginmoneygiving and search #Swimming across Loch Fyne#.The former gasworks site in Dunoon is to be used for a special drive-in cinema.With Dunoon#s Studio Cinema closed in line with government coronavirus restrictions, Dunoon#s Business Improvement District PABID is behind plans for this unique event.Through its Dunoon Presents Facebook page, PABID announced last week: #We are excited to announce Dunoon will be having its own drive-in cinema at the gas works. Date will be announced soon.#Public demand for films which might be shown seem to be veering on Facebook towards the classics such as Breakfast at Tfany#s and the Bond movies, but organisers have hinted there might be a Disney treat in store for youngsters earlier in the day.Don#t forget the popcorn, drinks and sweets, which should be available to buy from Studio Cinema before the curtain up at the gasworks drive-in.With the cautious easing of coronavirus restrictions, Mid Argyll Radio Sailing has been allowed to start sailing again, on a limited basis.The club was established in  to encourage and promote model yacht sailing in all its formats.Sailing to date has taken place on Loch a# Bharain, a lochan adjoining the Crinan Canal near lock nine.If you fancy having a go, visit www.midargyllradiosailing.org.uk.Rosemary Neagle of Carnasserie Farm sent us this photograph of a former Home Guard hut to the north of Kilmartin.#It was situated overlooking the Oban road in case the enemy approached from that direction,# Rosemary explained.#My mother remembers her uncle and a few others manned the hut and #played about with guns#. It was a basic lean-to structure with a corrugated iron roof that has now rusted into the ground.#These days it is only used by sheep to shelter from wind and rain.#

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: rugby-players-hailed-helping-prepare-golf-course
story: GALA rugby players have been thanked for helping to prepare a local golf course for reopening.Torwoodlee Golf Club welcomed members back on Fridayafter First Minister Nicola Sturgeon eased lockdown restrictions.Club chairman Robin Brydon said greenkeepers had been helped by Gala RFC players.He thanked the volunteers for their "great efforts" in rolling turf and raking bunkers.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoWersquod be delighted to help other local sports clubs and organisations in these times ndash get in touch."You can contact the rugby club through its Facebook page or by emailing info@galarfc

title: runner-ticking-off-borders-towns---seen-yet
story: A GALASHIELS man is running through a dozen towns for a fundraiser in memory of his late sister.Craig Lowrie, , challenged himself to complete km in each town during the common riding season.Mr Lowrie is dedicating his efforts to his late sister Donna Cameron, who died in a car crash on June , .The keen amateur footballer said: "The money that I raise in my sisters memory will be split between common riding committees across the Borders, with donors choosing which towns festival their money will go towards."Mr Lowriersquos son was the Braw Lad in Galashiels last year ndash and now Mr Lowrie is running through each town that Robbie visited."My sister loved the common riding season, and was so proud and excited for Robbie ahead of the big day last year, said Mr Lowrie."Sadly, she died just a few weeks before and didnrsquot get the chance to watch her nephew carry out his duties."Donations will help common riding committees make up for not being able to hold fundraisers due to the coronavirus pandemic, says Mr Lowrie.However,donors prefer, they can ask for their money to go to the childrens ward at the Borders General Hospitalndash another cause close to Mr Lowriersquos heart.He said: "The staff in ward  were fantastic with my daughter Jorga, who had a number of blood transfusions during the first six years of her le, due to having a rare blood disorder."Thankfully, she is well on the road to recovery, and wersquore very grateful to all the staff in the ward. Its great to be able to give something back."Mr Lowrie, who plays football for Selkirk Victoria AFC, has already gone the distance in Hawick, Selkirk and Melrose ndash and will arrive in Peebles tomorrow .His online GoFundMe campaign has proved a success over the last few weeks.A total of pound, has been donated by  people [as at .am, June ], and the fundraiser has been shared  times on social media."The majority of money so far has been donated to either ward  at the BGH or the Braw Ladsrsquo Gathering committee of Galashiels," said Mr Lowrie."Im keen to raise as much awareness as possible for the cause so that other towns can benefit too."Other towns on the list are Jedburgh, Duns, Innerleithen, Kelso, Musselburgh, Lauder and Coldstream.And on June , Mr Lowrie will run km in Galashiels, one year after Robbie led proceedings.He said: "Hopefully, Ill be able to get some sort of [socially distanced] crowd to cheer me on as Im going up Scott Street, where the horses would normally go."Im trying to convince Robbie to join me for a part of it, but hes not agreed to anything yet."Although Innerleithen does not have a common riding, they do have a games week in July.And as Donna lived much of her le there, Mr Lowrie thought it would be fitting for the towns festival to be able to benefit.He said: "Ive been blown away with peoples generosity."Id like to say a big thank you as well to local companies ndash including Tesco in Galashiels, who donated blister packs, water and Haribos."The blister packs will definitely be needed, as Ive been running in the same pair of shoes for months and one of the toes has worn away!Details of the fundraiser can be found here.

title: record-low-alcohol-sales-scotland-last-year
story: ALCOHOL sales in Scotland remain at their lowest level on record for a second year, a study has found.A total of . litres of alcohol was sold per adult last year, the equivalent of  units per person each week.The annual Monitoring and Evaluating Scotlands Alcohol Strategyreport found sales were at the same level as , maintaining the lowest level since recording began in .Minimum unit pricing came into force on May ,  and requires all licensed premises in Scotland to set a floor price of p per unit of alcohol.The average price of alcohol sold in Scottish supermarkets and off-licences rose to  pence per unitin , up from ppu in .Meanwhile, the volume of pure alcohol sold in Scotland was  per cent higher than in England and Wales, representing the smallest dference since .Alcohol-specic death rates are consistently higher in Scotland than south of the border.The rates are nearly twice as high for men and  per cent higher for women.The most recent figures for  show , people died in Scotland due to a cause wholly attributable to alcohol.Deaths in the  per cent most deprived areas were more than four times higher than in the  per cent least deprived areas.Public Health Scotland, the agency that has taken over responsibility for MESAS, said too many people were exceeding the guidelines on alcohol despite the encouraging trends.Lucie Giles, public health intelligence principal, said: "Population level alcohol consumption in Scotland has remained at the level the MESAS programme reported last year."Based on alcohol sales, average alcohol consumption in  is estimated at . litres of pure alcohol per adult in Scotland."This is the lowest we have seen in the available data and maintains the smallest dference between Scotland and England  Wales since the early s."Despite these encouraging trends, the most recent survey data shows that nearly a quarter of adults exceeded the revised low-risk weekly drinking guidelines, and that drinkers in the lowest income group are likely to consume more."She added: "An average of  people per week are still dying as a result of their alcohol consumption and again this is not spread evenly throughout the population ndash those in the most deprived areas are more likely to be hospitalised or die because of an alcohol-related cause."Like all harm caused by alcohol, this is preventable."Public Health Scotland will continue to monitor and evaluate Scotlands alcohol strategy, so we can continue to gauge progress and understand what works to reduce the harm alcohol causes."

title: borders-couple-lot-celebrate-week
story: A BORDERS couple have toasted a double celebration this week after clocking up a pair of milestones.Jim Dyer and his we Margaret, of Peebles, marked  years of marriage on June  ndash the same day that Jim turned ."Its a case of loving to live together, said Jim. ldquoAnd theres been nothing closer than the last  weeks, he joked.The coronavirus pandemic scuppered the couplersquos hopes of meeting up with their -year-old son Nigel, who lives in Aberdeen.But Mr and Mrs Dyer have spent their anniversary week ldquotalking about memories, according to Jim."You could be in worse places than Peebles, he said.Margaret and Jim Dyer celebrated two milestones in Peebles on June , . Photo: Helen BarringtonJim and Margaret met in the mid-s when Jim began an engineering apprenticeship at the same Motherwell company Margaret worked for.Jim also spent time as a marine reserve until , going on to tiethe knot with Margaret in ."I dont regret a minute, Jim told the Border . "Shes a wonderful girl.Jims career in engineering took him and Margaret around the world ndash including Australia, Africa, Canada and Chile ndash before Jim took early retirement from the Anglo American Corporation in .The couple have lived in Peebles for  years, where they say they are "happy being part of the community".When asked for the secret to a successful -year marriage, Jim said: "Consideration, compassion, an awareness that no two people are alike."And love ndash we loved each other, and still do."I believe love makes the world go round, and is given by the le force of God."Im not a religious person but I have a faith."On their partnership today, Jim described himself as ldquovery fortunate, adding: "We care for each other ndash Im her memory and shes my eyes.

title: borders-girl-wants-live-turtles
story: A BORDERS youngster has vowed to help ldquosave animals that are dying in rubbish by cycling  miles in a month.Six-year-old Ava Wheatley, from Tweedbank, decided to raise money for the Marine Conservation Society with a sponsored bike ride.Mum Kirsty said: ldquoEvery day she asks to fit in a cycle ndash shersquos so dedicated.Ava was spurred into action by a home-school lesson about people ldquomaking a dference, said Kirsty.After making a banner inspired by a young turtle injured by plastic pollution, Ava asked: ldquoWhat next ldquoI had to explain that a banner wouldnrsquot fix it, said Kirsty, ldquoso we spent time looking into what to do."We tried to help her understand that itrsquos not the animals that are the problem, itrsquos people.It was during their research that Ava and Kirsty came across the Marine Conservation Societyrsquos beach cleans.To support the charity, Ava is cycling the equivalent distance of Melrose to East Lothianrsquos Yellowcraig beach.Kirsty said itrsquos been lovely to see her daughter become so passionate about helping the environment.ldquoShe keeps saying she wants them [turtles] to live with us.ldquoShe believes shersquos fixed it, but wersquore working so that shersquos not disappointed.At the time of publication, Ava had raised more than three times her target of pound.ldquoItrsquos crazy, I was a bit apprehensive, I felt everyone has something going on, Kirsty said.ldquoAvarsquos been spurred on by everyonersquos generosity.To donate to Avarsquos fundraiser, you can visit this site.

title: travis-perkins-borders-job-losses-expected
story: BORDERS job losses are expected following news that Travis Perkins is closing sites across the UK.The buildersrsquo merchants, which has three branches in the Borders, plans to shut  stores - affecting , jobs.This newspaper has seen an email from Travis Perkins stating that the Peebles branch ldquowill not be reopening.Travis Perkinsrsquo media office has been contacted for comment about the sites in Peebles, Kelso and St Boswells.The companyrsquos chief executive Nick Roberts said: ldquoWhilst we have experienced improving trends more recently, we do not expect ato pre-Covid trading conditions for some time and consequently we have had to take the very dficult decision to begin consultations on the closure of selected branches and to reduce our workforce to ensure we can protect the Group as a whole.ldquoThis is in no way a reflection on those employees impacted and we will do everything we can to support them during this process.He added: ldquoWhile there has been a signicant recovery in trading volumes in recent weeks, it is evident that the UK is facing a recession and this will have a corresponding impact on the demand for building materials during  and .The redundancies make up about nine per cent of the total workforce, the company said.Former Peebles branch manager Kevin Smith told us that the Dovecot Road site has traditionally made ldquoa hell of a profit.He said a previous managing director for the company described the branch as a ldquohidden gem.Mr Smith said: ldquoI am shocked and saddened that this branch is closing.ldquoIt has always been a profitable wee branch. title: borders-hotel-chief-ditch-2m-rule-distancing
story: A HOTEL chief is calling for the two-metre social-distancing rule to be dropped.Stobo Castle chairman Stephen Winyard believes thousands of hospitality workers will be made redundant across the UKthe guidance continues unchanged.Mr Winyard, , said: ldquoThe impact on the tourism sector will be horrendous in terms of jobs lost.Instead of the two-metre recommendation, Mr Winyard would like to see a one-metre rule introduced.Tweeddale MP David Mundell has sympathised with the suggestion, agreeing that the guidance should be reviewed.Mr Winyard, a director of the luxury Peeblesshire hotel, believes the example set by some other countries should be followed.He points to the one-metre rule in France, as well as Germanyrsquos .-metre recommendation."The World Health Organisationsays one metre is safe, said Mr Winyard. ldquoWeve gone to the most extreme [distancing measures] in the world."He added: ldquoA decision to halve social distancing will help to kickstart this sectorrsquos recovery, save countless jobs and in following the WHOrsquos guidance on this subject, still allow our respective governments to discharge their sacred duty of safeguarding the publicrsquos health.Asked to comment on Mr Winyardrsquos plea, Mr Mundell, of the Conservatives, said: "There appears to be a weight of evidence from a number of countries and organisations that one-metre distancing can strike a reasonable balance between safeguarding health and providing a practical way of working."Hospitality and tourism are amongst the most important employers in Tweeddale ndash and right across my constituency ndash and many jobs and businesses depend on workable safe solutions being established as soon as possible."It is vital that the Scottish Government reviews the two-metre rule to help ensure the sector is best placed to come out of lockdown providing a safe and appealing environment for both customers and staff."Meanwhile, Tweeddale MSP Christine Grahame told the Peeblesshire Newsthat she appreciates the dficulties posed by the two-metre rule, but she added that it exists for peoplersquos safety.The SNP member said: ldquoThe virus has not gone away and the margins for ensuring the virus does not take off again remain tight.ldquoThe scientic advice has not changed and that is why the two-metre rule is in place, to protect everyone.ldquoI understand and sympathise greatly with the limitations this rule puts on many businesses but the priority must still be to protect everyonersquos health.ldquoHowever, along with all the other measures, the two-metre rule is under constant review and any relaxation will happenand when it is deemed safe to do so.ldquoWe know the restrictions cause harms of their own, and they will not be kept in place for a moment longer than is necessary.Mr Winyard said he views the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach as ldquovery cautious.But he added that he believes any reduction in social distancing would have to take into account Scotlands lsquoR ratersquo and the effectiveness of the track and trace programme.

title: phase-2-13-new-changes-scotlands-lockdown-restrictions-eased
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today announced a further easing of lockdown measures in Scotland.Throughout the last week, the First Minister had indicated her optimism at moving the country into Phase  of the four-phased route map out of lockdown restrictions.The decision was made at the three-weekly formal review of the measures, following a further suppression of the coronavirus in Scotland ndash with the NRS revealing yesterday the number of virus-related deaths fell for the seventh week in a row.But what does Phase  actually mean for you From seeing family and friends to outdoor shopping, here are the biggest changes from the latest easing of lockdown.From June Shielding peopleFrom today, people who are shielding can go outdoors for exercise.Shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activity, such as golf, from tomorrow.From tomorrow, people who are shielding can also meet people from one other household.From Friday, June Seeing friends and familyThe First Minister today revealed people can enter other households to use the toilet - but should continue meeting outdoors.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside - with the maximum of two extra households and eightpeople.This is in addition to the measures from Phase , which included sunbathing sitting outdoors, and visiting other households outdoors and in gardens.Extended householdFrom tomorrow, people who live alone or with children under  can have a bubble with one other household - you can visit indoors and stay overnight.This has to be with this household only.TransportPublic transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.Face masks will be mandatory on all public transport.The First Minister says the five-mile limit for leisure and recreational purposes will remain for now - "remain as close as possible to local area" until Phase .There is no five-mile limit for visiting family and friends.From Monday, June DentistsAll dental practices can reopen to see patients with urgent care needs from Phase  ndash meanwhile procedures which generate aerosols will remain at emergency dental hubs.SportsThe guidance also says the resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is allowed.As with the previous Phase, unrestricted outdoors exercise is permitted, so long as you adhere to distancing measures. Non-contact sports like golf, hiking, fishing etc remain allowed.However, gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .WorshipThe route map also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .,params: .pushFrom Monday, June ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans fornon-essential retail units to reopen form June - but these will have to have outside entrances. Therefore shopping centres cannot reopen.Drive-thrus and garden centres were already permitted to reopen under the previous easing of measures.SportsSports courts and playgrounds are now permitted to reopen across Scotland.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.MarriagesUnder Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with the number of attendees kept to a minimal.Moving houseRelaxation on restrictions on housing moves.EducationCollege and university staff canto make essential preparations for restart in Phase .These institutionswill not until Phase , with schools set toacross Scotland from August .

title: clarks-closes-shoe-shop-galashiels
story: CLARKS has closed its Galashiels shoe shop which employs nine staff.The company has decided not to renew the lease at the Gala Water site.A spokesperson says the closure is ldquoin no way related to the coronavirus pandemic.A statement reads: "At Clarks, we continually review all of our stores to ensure that they are the right size and located in the right areas in order to provide the best possible offering and environment to our customers."After careful consideration, we have decided to no longer trade at Galashiels."Decisions have yet to be made about workersrsquo futures, the company says, with employees currently engaged in talks.The spokesperson said  stores are closing across the UK, including four in Scotland.

title: shielding-people-scotland-can-cannot-phase-2
story: THE First Minister yesterday outlined plans to provide a ldquoreal improvement to the quality of le of those shielding in Scotland.As part of measures being eased as the country moved into Phase  of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon revealed that anyone shielding would experience change immediately.There are around , people in the shielding group,which includes organ transplant recipients, those on active chemotherapy, those with severe lung disease, those with certain metabolic diseases, the signicantly immunosuppressed and pregnant women with underlying heart problems.They also included anyonedeemed vulnerable by primary care physiciansAt the start of the pandemic they were all sent a letter telling them to stay indoors and take extra precautions until June .Last week, Nicola Sturgeon extended that, telling them that they would need to shield until the end of July.So what has changed for people shielding in Scotland Here we outline what you can and cannot do now we have moved into Phase .Irsquom in a shielding household, what canI do now Confirming her pledge last week, the First Minister revealed that anyone who is shielding , can nowgo outdoors for exercise ndash whether it be a walk, a wheel or cycle.But the First Minister added an extra easing. From today ndash Friday, June  ndash shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activities.This includes things likegolf, fishingand hillwalking.Ms Sturgeon also revealed that those shielding can meet outdoors with people from one other household ndash however these are to be in groups of no more than eight.When you do go outside, you are urged to choose times and areas that are quiet ndash and wash your hands thoroughly as soon as you get back home.What can I still NOT do The First Minister urged people who are shielding to ldquocontinue to be extremely cautious ndash remaining at least  metres away from other people at all times, ldquoevenyou live with the person yoursquore out with.Unlike the general public, you cannot go inside someone rsquos house, or allow someone from another household to go inside yours ndash even to just use the toilet.What has the reaction been Brian Sloan, chief executive of Age Scotland, described the announcement as a ldquolight at the end of the tunnel for older people.He said: ldquoThe easing of lockdown for hundreds of thousands of older people living alone will come as a huge relief.ldquoSo many older people have endured lockdown without any face to face contact with family or friends for three months now, and it has been extremely dficult for them.ldquoFor the half a million over-s in Scotland who donrsquot use the internet, there hasnrsquot even been the option of video calls with loved ones. They have had to rely on the phone for conversation.ldquoThe result of such prolonged isolation is that loneliness levels are through the roof and having a profound impact on the mental and physical health of older people.He added: ldquoTodayrsquos announcement is a small step towards normality, and must of course be done in compliance with safety guidelines, but at last there is light at the end of the tunnel for our older people who have felt very cut off from society during this pandemic.ldquoThey can now look forward to seeing family and friends and when it is safe to do so, being part of their communities again.

title: covid-alert-level-system-changes-mean
story: THE UKrsquos chief medical officers have agreed to downgrade the coronavirus alert level from four to three following a "steadyand continuing"decrease in cases in all four nations.Localised outbreaks of COVID- are still "likely"to occur, the advisers warned - and the virus remains in general circulation.But the downgrading ndash recommended by the Joint Biosecurity Centrendash means transmission of coronavirus is no longer considered to be ldquohigh or rising exponentially.Englandrsquos Professor Chris Whitty, Northern Irelandrsquos Dr Michael McBride, Scotlandrsquos Dr Gregor Smith and Walesrsquo Dr Chris Jones agreed with the JBCrsquos recommendation.But what is the alert system and how does it work Heres what you need to know.What is the alert system The Covid Alert Levels system was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson in his televised address to the nation on May .The system is similar to that used to establish the terrorist threat and will be run by a new Joint Biosecurity Centre.It has five tiers from level one to five based on the spread of COVID- through the UK.The Covid- alert level system. Picture credit: PA GraphicsHow does it work Mr Johnson said that the UKs current alert level will be determined primarily by the virusrsquo reproduction rate ndash the average number of people that will contract coronavirus from an infected person ndash and the number of coronavirus cases.The level will then inform the government what measures are needed to combat the spread of the virus, with higher levels requiring stricter controls.What are the dferent levels When the scheme was launched the country was at level four which means a ldquoCOVID- epidemic is in general circulation, transmission is high or rising exponentially.The system says that current social distancing measures and restrictions should remain in place.Level five is when transmission is high or rising but also when there was a risk of healthcare services being overwhelmed and will require an increase in social distancing measures.Level one means there COVID- is no longer known to be in the UK and the only action should be ldquoroutine international monitoring.Level three is when the epidemic is in general circulation and gradual easing of restrictions can take place, while level two is when the number of cases and transmission is low and ldquono or minimal restrictions are required.But under level two there will be enhanced testing, tracing, monitoring and screening.Who monitors and sets the level Mr Johnson said he was establishing a new Joint Biosecurity Centre to run the alert system.Cabinet Office documents said the centre will provide real-time analysis and assessment of COVID- outbreaks at a community level to enable rapid action to stop spikes in infection.It will also advise on specic actions which can be taken to manage rising numbers of infections, such as closing schools or businesses.The centre will also inform the chief medical officers of a change in the COVID- Alert level who will then advise ministers.

title: borders-rugby-11-clubs-getting-money-running-costs
story: BORDERS rugby clubs are getting money to help cover running costs during the coronavirus pandemic.Scottish Rugby launched its Club Hardship Fundin March, with clubs across the country able to apply for up to pound, to help with costs up to July.Higher claims were considered in ldquoexceptional circumstances.The list of successful clubs has now been released - and there are  in the Borders.Melrose RFCrsquos finance director Graeme Burgess says his club is grateful for the money.ldquoThis scheme, along with support from government and other bodies, have helped to ensure that we are able to see out the most financially challenging period in the clubrsquos history, Mr Burgess said.Scottish Rugby chief executive Mark Dodson said: ldquoWe launched the Club Hardship Fund in order to offer support to clubs at what has proved to be an extremely challenging time for those involved in the sport at community level.ldquoI am pleased that each applicant club will receive direct financial assistance to help where they need it most so that when rugby does resume, they are well placed to become community hubs once more.This is the full list of Borders clubs which have been awarded moneyHawick RFCEarlston RFCGala RFCPeebles RFCMelrose RFCJed-Forest RFCSt Boswells RFCHawick Linden RFCDuns RFCGala YM RFCSelkirk RFC

title: confirmed-galashiels-tanning-salon-broke-lockdown-rules
story: A TANNING salon broke official guidance by reopening too early during lockdown, Scottish Borders Councilsays.Tantalize, on Channel Street in Galashiels, opened its doors on Monday , during phase one of Scotlandrsquos route out of lockdown.But the salon has been forced to close after council officials ruled that Scottish Government guidelines were breached.Salon owner Conrad Mackenzie Campbell said: "I have spoken to the council environmental health board and they have advised I remain closed.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced yesterdaythat Scotland has moved into phase two of the route out of lockdown.Shops can reopen from June , said Ms Sturgeon, but personal retail businesses must remain closed until phase three.An SBC spokesperson said: "The council was informed that a tanning salon in Galashiels was open this week."Our protective services team spoke to the owner and have confirmed the business should still be closed in line with current Scottish Government guidance."No further action will be taken at this time.As reported previously, the Border was approached by two readerswho said the salon opened this week.One of them, a Galashiels worker, claimed to have seen six people entering the premises at the same time.Responding to that claim, Mr Campbell says: "There has never been six people within the salon at any time."He added: "I opened the business making that decision based upon all factors and customer safety being number one."I have covered all safety aspects with social distancing and hygiene which is the priority."We have not broken any rules within the tanning shop."Non-essential shops in Scotland were ordered to close in March.

title: couples-living-apart-scotland-can-sleepover-today----rules
story: THE First Minister yesterday revealed news that many people across Scotland were waiting to hear.As part of the countryrsquos move into Phase  in the route map out of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for an lsquoextended householdrsquo.She said the Scottish Government was mindful of the ldquowider harms that come from the restrictions put in place to tackle the coronavirus ndash including ldquoloneliness and isolation, particular for older people living alone and lone parents.And while the idea of an extended household has wide-ranging benefits, therersquos one aspect in particular, sometimes dubbed a ldquosex bubble, that has people talking.The new arrangements, permitted from today, means that non-cohabiting couples - where at least one of them lives alone - can be reunited indoors without social distancing for the first time in three months.What can I do under an lsquoextended household rsquoWithin an extended household group, people will be able to meet indoors, without physical distancing and stay overnight - though onlythey wish.But they must continue to see any other households outdoors only, and stay more than  metres apart from them.Who can form one Only people who live alone, or who live only with children under -years-old, can form an extended household.The idea is it could allow, for example, a grandparent who lives on their own to form a group with another household in their family.It will allow a single parent and their children to join with another household for support.And, of course, couple who live apartcan be reunited and stay over.But, an important detail to note: people who are shielding cannot form an extended household.Can I have more than one extension No. A person should not form an extended household with more than one other household.Can I leave my lsquobubblersquo Yes, you can.Households can agree to end the arrangement at any time ndash but they should not then form a subsequent lsquobubblersquo with another household. So perhaps choose wisely.Whatsomeone in my lsquoextended householdrsquo gets coronavirus This is where it gets tricky.Put simply,one member of your extended household gets the virus, the entire group has to isolate.This is regardless of whether or not they are living in the same property.As an addition to that, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI would also encourage those who choose to form extended households to pay particular attention to hygiene measures ndash to reduce the risk that one household will bring the virus into another.When will this be extended to other groups of people The First Minister did not provide a date on when this could be extended to more people.But she added she will ldquoconsiderand to what extent we can expand it over the next few weeks, admitting it will not immediately make a dference to everyone.She urged the public to visit the Scottish Government websitefor more information, adding: ldquoWith the best will in the world, we cannot provide precise answers for every bespoke situation.ldquoSo when in doubt, use your judgement and err on the side of caution.

title: jeweller-shuts-galashiels-shop-permanently
story: JEWELLER H.Samuel has announced its Galashiels shop will close permanently in June.The company says the coronavirus pandemic sped up existing plans to shut some stores across the UK.A spokesperson said: "Our H. Samuel store in Galashiels is closing."Amid this challenging pandemic and fluid business conditions, we have accelerated a previous strategy to close some stores permanently starting this month.The spokesperson would not comment on the impact on Galashiels staff.Shoe shop Clarks has also announced the closure of its outletin the town.Meanwhile, stationery business WHSmith has quashed rumours that it was planning to do likewise.A spokesperson says the company has ldquono intention of closing the Channel Street site.

title: seeing-smiley-faces-just-brightens-morning
story: FOR  years, Catherine Mason has been waving to school pupils as they pass her house in Peebles every morning.Le in lockdown has been particularly hard on elderly residents living in isolation who are lonely.But -year-old Catherine simply misses morning greetings from her wee friends ndash the children from Priorsford Primary and Peebles High School.The emotional exchange has warmed the hearts of her neighbours, who contacted our sister paper thePeeblesshire News.Catherine has lived in Peebles since , when she and her late husband George bought a house in The Meadows, which is a popular route for children on their way to school.Every morning Catherine and George would be up before the school bell offering up a friendly wave to the youngsters as they passed by.Many of the kids would smile and wave back, and thus it became somewhat of a ritual.George, who owned Masons Butcher shop in Innerleithen, sadly passed away four years ago.ldquoHe was called the lsquoPie Manrsquo, said Catherine. ldquoHis pies were legendary.Even without her husband by her side, Catherine carried on the tradition of waving to the school pupils.ldquoThey just make my day, she said. ldquoI get up and get dressed and make sure Irsquom at the window in time for them passing by."Seeing their smiley faces just brightens my morning.However, a few years ago pupils passed by and Mrs Mason was nowhere to be seen, her blinds were shut and alarm bells started to ring.Catherine told us: ldquoThey went into school crying telling their teacher the lady who waves to us wasnrsquot there.ldquoThe school alerted a neighbour who had a key and she came to check and saw that my bed was made.ldquoDuring the evening I had a bad fall and pressed my buzzer and was taken to hospital.The poor souls were very worried. When I got home from hospital four boys brought me some beautul flowers and the tears were rolling down my cheeks ndash I was so touched.On Catherinersquos th birthday, her neighbours decorated the outside of her house with balloons and bunting ndash and she had a choir of pupils singing lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.We asked Catherine how she has been been feeling since COVID- forced early closure of the schools.Describing herself as ldquolost without the pupils, she said: ldquoIn the mornings I rush to get down the stairs for them passing, forgetting that the schools are closed. The street is so quiet.ldquoSome of the high school boys go past on their bikes and still give me a wave, and one mum brought her daughter over to give me a coloured drawing which has pride of place in my house.ldquoI donrsquot have any family of my own, so I miss them. I miss their lovely smiles.The Queen referenced Dame Vera Lynnrsquos wartime classic Wersquoll Meet Againin her recent address to the nation.For Catherine the lyrics are very poignant, as she told me: ldquoI donrsquot know when Irsquoll see them again.I reminded Catherine that the schools will be reopening in August, so now she knows when and where shersquoll meet her wee friends again.Until then, she says shersquoll keep smiling through until that sunny day where shersquoll be standing at her window ready to wave again.

title: borders-castle-bans-day-visitors-rest-2020
story: A BORDERS castle will stay closed to day visitors for the rest of , bosses say.Trustees of Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, have made the decision due to the coronavirus pandemic.Edward Maitland-Carew said: "With so much uncertainty and having weighed up all our options, it is with great sadness that we have had to make the very dficult decision to not open the castle to the day visitor this year."These are challenging times for museums like Thirlestane Castle who rely so heavily on visitor income to preserve the castle and its collections."The th century castle, regarded as one of the finest in Scotland, is home to the Maitland family.Although they have ruled out visits from day-trippers, they hope to open some overnight accommodation in July.Plans have been drawn up to reopen five self-catering holiday apartments, with the expectation that Scotland will move into phase three of lockdown easing on July .A castle spokesperson said: "Staff are being trained in new measures to protect both themselves and guests, including self-check in services and enhanced hygiene and cleaning procedures".The owner plans to reopen the castle and grounds to day visitors in March .

title: five-strict-scotrail-rules-face-coverings-become-mandatory-public-transport
story: SCOTRAIL have put in place strict new rules to ensure safer travel while using the railways.The First Minister revealed on Thursday that face coverings would be mandatory on public transport from today, as she outlined Scotlandrsquos move into Phase  of the route map out of lockdown.Transport Secretary Michael Matheson has urged people to continue limiting their travel, asking people to ldquoleave space on public transport for those who need it most.He also urged employers to carefully manage their phased ing of staff to work with figures suggesting up to % of employees could travel to their normal workplace in this phase.When Scotland was in full lockdown, the figure was just %.It could also result in an increase in the number of passengers on public transport by around by a third from the current levels of around , per day.But what are the rules for using ScotRail trains According to ScotRail, these are the five key rules to remember when travelling:Do not travelyou feel unwell or have a temperature.Travel away from the main commuting timeswherever possible, as trains will be busiest around then. The earliest and latest trains serve key workers, like NHS and care home staff.If you think itrsquos not safe to board a train, donrsquot do it and wait for another service.Wear a face mask or covering and, where possible, maintain physical distancing.Be patient. You might not be able to board your first choice of train, as physical distancing means most seats need to be left empty.Remember that from today, face coverings are mandatory on public transport in Scotland.Read the guidance including information on exemptions for specic medical reasons and children under five: https:t.co yELnwvj#StayTravelSafepic luJVBbkFZCmdash Transport ScotlandJune , David Simpson, ScotRail Operations Director, said: ldquoThe position on face coverings is now absolutely clear and we are urging customers to take collective responsibility and follow the Scottish Government rules on their mandatory use.ldquoWe are doing everything we can to help customers get used to the changes in rail travel and thatrsquos why, for a limited time, we will be providing face masks at our busiest stations. But Scotlandrsquos Railway canrsquot guarantee physical distancing at all stages of a customerrsquos journey.ldquoThe message remains the same as it has been since the start of the pandemic: only travelyour journey is essential and follow our five rules for safer travel. It will help to keep you, your fellow customers, and our staff safe.To support customers, ScotRail are providing face masks free of charge at  of Scotlandrsquos busiest stations.Those stations are:#bull Glasgow Queen Streetbull Edinburgh Haymarket,params: .pushbull Glasgow Centralbull Edinburgh Waverleybull Invernessbull Aberdeenbull Argyle Streetbull Exhibition Centrebull Johnstonebull Ayrbull Paisley Gilmour Streetbull Linlithgowbull Falkirk Highbull Bathgatebull Airdriebull Hyndlandbull Dalmuirbull MotherwellFollow our five rules for safer travel:## Dont travelyou feel unwell.## Avoid these main commuting times .## Dont boardyou think its not safe.## Cover your face  maintain physical distancing.## Be patient, most seats need to be empty. pic ZddPAJXmdash ScotRailJune , Does everyone have to wear a mask The majority of the public has to wear some form of face covering on public transport from today.But there are some exemptions to the rule.They are:Children under fivePolice officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with a health condition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.

title: council-refuses-name-borders-firms-given-virus-funding
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilis refusing to say which businesses have received a "small business support grant".The local authority manages a portion of the Scottish Governments Business Support Fund, with grants of pound, and pound, being awarded to local firms struggling during the coronavirus pandemic.This newspaper asked the council to release a list of the , businesses which have been given help.But an SBC spokesperson said: "This [list] isnrsquot something we would provide."As at June , the council has approved grants worth a total of pound. million.

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: ON Thursday, the First Minister outlined a wave of new measures being eased across Scotland aswe enter Phase  of the four-part route map out of lockdown.Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsmanthat it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

title: germany-coronavirus-r-value-spiked-2-88-weekend
story: The R rate of coronavirus in Germany rose sharply atthe weekend from below one to between . to ., according to official figures.The British security minister James Brokenshire described the rise as "concerning".He said:"It is concerning to see the situation inGermanyand its why we are informed in our actions by experience from around the world, why the chief scientic officer, the chief medical officer, speak to their counterparts in dferent parts of the world to ensure that we are applying the best learning and the best experience in informing our next steps."So, how does the R measure work The ldquoR value, or infection rate, refers to the number of people that one infected person will pass the virus to on average.Coronavirus has an estimated reproduction number of three, meaning an infected person will likely pass the virus on to at least three other people.A reproduction number that is higher than one poses a signicant risk, as the number of cases can increase rapidly, making it harder for the spread to be contained.That means thatGermanyrsquos R value is accurate, for every  people infected an additional  are likely to become affected.Why has the R valuerisen The R value has seen a surge following a series of outbreaks at hospitals, care homes, religious gatherings and refugee centres.One of the largest outbreaks took place at an abattoir in the countryrsquos north leading to the closure of schools and the launch of an investigation.Abattoir company Toennies, in western Germany, stopped production after hundreds of employees tested positive for coronavirusThe Robert Koch Institute,which measures the number of cases in the country, explained that the spike in the R value is partly due to the relatively small number of cases.Shouldthe UK be worried The spike in the R value is undoubtedly concerning, but the number of new cases across Germany remains relatively low.The Robert Koch Institute underlined the need for caution, but said that ldquolocal outbreaks have a relatively strong influence on the value.In a statement it said: Further developments need to be monitored closely during the upcoming days, especially in regard to whether case numbers are increasing outside of outbreak contexts.

title: borders-traders-excited-farmers-market-eyes-return
story: BORDERS traders are "delighted" at the prospect of attending an outdoor market next weekend as lockdown restrictions are eased.Organisers of Selkirk Farmers Market hope to welcome stall holders for the first time since March .Selkirkshire councillor Caroline Cochrane said: "I think it will give everyone a boost, and help folks morale."Local businesses have missed three markets during lockdown, but the events will be allowed to restart from next week.Ms Cochrane, owner of Selkirk clothes shop Liberty Star Trading, is one of the markets organisers.She told the Border she has received keen support from some of the core stall holders, including Allan Walker of the Selkirk Distillery.Mr Walker expressed much enthusiasm for the latest lting of coronavirus restrictions, which allow outdoors markets to ."Were absolutely delighted ndash delighted is an understatement," said Mr Walker."Weve lost out on  events during lockdown, including a German festival."It will give the community heart to be back together."Selkirk Farmers Market was forced to cancel its last three events as Scottish Government guidance banned public gatherings.The reopening of the market is not set in stone, however ndash as safety details must be confirmed beforehand.Jill Scott, owner of The Dessert Diva in Kelso, said organisers and stall holders will have to think about how to conduct their business in the new normal.She said: "Wed have to rethink how we display items."We have a screen, but will we have to wrap every item inidually "We need to get back to normality, but safety is important."Ms Cochrane, meanwhile, said she will ensure there is enough room for the eight expected stalls and their customers, adding she will look into creating a one-way system."Its a good place to start, as long as we tick all the boxes for safety."I think it will give everyone a boost, and help folks morale."People have been saying they miss treats."It would be nice to think we can have a sunny morning."

title: coronavirus-vaccine-uk-scientists-share-positive-update
story: Two doses of a coronavirus vaccinemadeby UK researchers produce a greater antibody response than a single dose, astudy in pigs has revealed.The ChAdOx nCoV-vaccine -developed by the University of Oxford - is currently undergoing human trials and it is hoped an effective vaccine could be ready later this year.Previous research indicated that macaques were protected against lung disease after a single immunisation.Now the Pirbright Institute, working with the University of Oxford, has shown that two doses of the Covid- vaccine might produce a greater immune response in pigs and therefore be a more effective approach to developing a protective response.What did the study find In the study, researchers saw a marked increase in neutralising antibodies, which bind to the virus in a way that blocks infection.It is not yet known what level of immune response will be required to protect humans against SARS-CoV- .Researchers said the finding in pigs is important as it suggests that two doses of the new vaccine could potentially give signicantly more protection in humans than a single dose.But they said further research in humans is required.What has Professor Bryan Charleston said Professor Bryan Charleston, director of the Pirbright Institute, said: ldquoThese results look encouraging that administering two injections with the same vaccine boosts antibody responses that can neutralise the virus, but it is the response in humans that is important.ldquoThe pig has proved to be a valuable model for testing human vaccines for other diseases to give an indication of the type of immune response induced and testing dferent doses.ldquoPigs are more physiologically similar to humans than some other animal models ndash for example, their body weight and metabolic rate ndash and are more accessible than studies using non-human primates.In the research, the pigs were split into two groups, with both receiving an initial dose of the vaccine, and one group receiving an identical booster immunisation on day  of the study.Latest developments are very encouragingProfessor Simon Graham, the lead author of the study, said: ldquoWhile it remains to be determined what immune responses are required to effectively protect people against Covid-, the demonstration that ChAdOx nCoV- induces both neutralising antibody and T cell responses is very encouraging.ldquoIt is likely that a combination of these responses would act in synergy to prevent and control infection, as we and others have recently shown in the context of experimental flu vaccines.What has the reaction been to this update Dr Stephen Grfin, associate professor in the school of medicine, University of Leeds, added: ldquoThe work done at Pirbright is an encouraging advance in support of the Oxford vaccine on three important fronts.,params: .pushldquoFirst, it has been conducted in a large animal model, namely pigs, which we know recapitulate human-like responses to influenza vaccines better than many other systems.ldquoSecond, it shows that a second dose of the vaccine, a so-called lsquoprime-boostrsquo strategy, gives rise to far better responses than a single inoculation, which might allay concerns arising from some of the earlier work on this and other spike-targeting vaccines.ldquoThird, it shows that the prime-boost strategy may well be achievable using the same vaccine rather than having to switch to an alternative  for the second dose, which could conceivably delay roll-out of the vaccination programme.ldquoWhilst these studies will need to be repeated within human subjects, and the precise nature and longevity of the responses might require further investigation, this is a heartening study that can be built upon and ideally followed by other potential vaccine s for SARS-CoV-.

title: staycation-five-scotlands-photogenic-places-visit-lockdown-eases
story: WITH lockdown measures slowly beginning to ease and the coronavirus continuing to be suppressed, itrsquos hard to blame some members of the public to begin planning a holiday.After exactly three months of lockdown things are starting to look up ndash and just last week it was revealed Scotlandrsquos tourism sector ndash including hotels, pubs and restaurants ndash could reopen from July .And with our beautul scenery, immersing history and friendly locals, therersquos no wonder why some research shows more than half of Brits are eyeing up a lsquostaycationrsquo this year rather than opting to go abroad.With that in mind, wersquove detailed outfiveof the most photogenic lsquostaycationrsquo locations to visit in Scotland once lockdown measures are eased.Harris, Outer HebridesWhen thinking about a lsquostaycationrsquo in Scotland, itrsquos understandable that a beach holiday isnrsquot the first thing on your mind.But the Outer Hebrides beaches are some of the most beautul in Europe ndash and it would be hard to blame youyou thought it was somewhere in the Caribbeanhellip perhaps only the temperature would give it away.In March, Luskentyre Bay on Harris was named as one of the top  beaches in the world by Tripadvisor.The far-flung, sandy outpost - which is reached by a single track road - was rated higher than sun-soaked destinations in Spain, the Caribbean, and the golden shores of Florida to take th spot in the prestigious s Travellers Choice Awards.Described by the sites visitors "as close to heaven as you could get", the expanse of Luskentyre Bay sits on the South of Harris, close to the isolated island of Taransay, where the seminal BBC reality series Castaway  was filmed.Tobermory, MullIt doesnrsquot take a tourism expert to identy the colourful harbour-front buildings of Tobermory from the popular childrenrsquos TV show Balamory.The capital of Mull, Tobermory is arguably one of the prettiest ports in Scotland thanks to the before-mentioned colourful houses and sheltered bay.Legend has it that Tobermory was the location of the sinking of Spanish Armada ship in , carrying gold bullion.You can find out all about the history of the area in the Mull museum ndash orgolf is more of your fancy then therersquos a nine-hole course sitting in the clfs above the bay.The ldquotough challenge offers panoramic views across to the Ardnamurchan Peninsula and, on a clear day, the Isle of Skye.The bay is also a departure point for whale watching and wildle cruises.Eilean Donan, HighlandsItrsquos the most photographed castle in Scotland and has been featured in blockbuster films including James Bond.Recognised around the world as one of the most iconic images of Scotland, itrsquos little wonder the castle is now one of the most visited attractions in the Scottish Highlands.,params: .pushStrategically located on its own little island overlooking the isle of Skye, the castle sits where three lochs ndash Loch Duich, Loch Long and Loch Alsh meet.Surrounded by the mountains of Kintail, visitors have the chance to wander around the internal rooms of the castle while also taking in the wonderful wildle that surrounds the island too ndash with porpoise, dolphins, otters and birdle sightings an often occurrence.Arran, North AyrshireThe Isle of Arran is often described as ldquoScotland in Miniature, soyoursquore looking for a quick staycation but with a lot to experience then look no further.The ever-changing coastline, dramatic mountain peaks, sheltered beaches and tasty local produce makes a holiday in Arran unforgettable.Donrsquot forget to pack your camera ndash with the stunning views of and from the islandrsquos largest mountain, Goatfell, worth capturing.Not only that but the island boasts a wealth of nature, including red squirrels, deer, golden eagles, otters, seals and basking sharks just waiting to be snapped up.Glenfinnan Viaduct, HighlandsMade ever more popular by the Harry Potter films, the Glenfinnan Viaduct attracts thousands of visitors from across the world every year.The special atmosphere and the stunning scenery overlooking the famous railway track makes for some magical images ndash no wonder why they chose it for the wizarding films.The famous viaduct carries the railway to Glenfinnan station across a ft span, ft above the ground ndash and the Jacobite steam train runs from here to Fort William and Mallaig in the summer months.Visitors are reminded, however, that trespassing on the railway line is extremely dangerous and they should stay clear of the tracks at all times.Full details of all the locations and more are available on Visit Scotlands website here.And remember: Do not travel for leisure until the Scottish Government guidance says it is acceptable to do so.

title: bbc-tv-licence-payments-75s-delayed-october
story: The BBC has again delayed making over-s pay for aTV licence.Those aged  and overwere due to have their free licences scrapped, and would instead have to pay the annual charge of pound. from August.But nowthe . million affected people wont have to pay until at least October.Heres everything you need to know.Why have the plans been delayed Initially, over-s would have had to begin paying in June, but plans were pushed back to August in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.TV licenses were deemed necessary to keep over-s informed as the pandemic spread, with that age bracket much moreat risk from the effects of COVID-.The chairman of the BBC, Sir David Clementi, said at the time: "The BBC board has decided to delay changes to over-s licence fees."We are in exceptional circumstances. Now is not the right time. We are fully focused on delivering our services to the public at this dficult time."Could the fee be scrapped entirely Tim Davie - due to assume the role of BBC Director General in September - is said to be opposed to scrapping free licences, fuelling hopes things may stay as they are.But he facesopposition from those who say the Beeb must make ends meet.The corporation has been left with a pound million shortfall as a result of coronavirus, and last week invited more than , staff to apply for voluntary redundancy.Those in support of free licences say the Government should pick up the cost.Lord Foulkes, the chairman of the All-Party Group for Ageing and Older People, said: "The Government should cover the cost as a social benefit and not burden the BBC, which is already strapped for cash."We will continue to work on this vital campaign alongside the likes of Age UK, as well as a growing number of MPs and peers."Caroline Abrahams, the charity director at Age UK, said: "While many older people are being advised to stay mostly at home, or are too worried to go out, free TV licences for over-s should continue."The last thing they need is to have to get to grips with a new TV licence scheme, or risk prosecutionthey get it wrong."Who will be affected The move to charge pensioners will be discussed at a BBC board meeting next month.If the plan for scrapping free licences goes ahead, from Octoberthe concession will be available only to households where someone receives Pension Credit.To qualy for Pension Credit, you must live in England, Scotland or Wales and you or your partner must have reached State Pension age.Around . million pensioners will lose out, it is thought.Free TV licences for over-s were introduced by Labour PM Gordon Brown, and were first paid for by a Labour government in .A new BBC charter which came into effect in  agreed that the corporation would take on the burden of paying for free licences by June  the Government stopped funding free TV licences for over-s and gave the BBC the responsibility to decide on the future of the concession.The  Conservative manesto contained a promise to continue the benefit.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be
