group, said: ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has seen many more people choosing to cycle and walk for exercise and essential journeys.ldquoThere seems to have been a fundamental sht in attitudes towards travel.ldquoAs our survey results show, because the roads are quieter, residents have been taking advantage of the safer environment.ldquoIt is also clear that people want to keep cycling or walking and expect more active travel choices.ldquoWe need council leaders to make a long-term commitment to invest in permanent infrastructure that will help people cycle and walk safely.Of the  people questioned, the vast majority expressed a desire to continue walkingand cyclingthe same, or even more, once lockdown restrictions are lted.Eighty nine per cent of people canvassed thought that East Lothian Council should signicantly invest more in cycling and walking infrastructure.Dominic Campanile, general manager of The Old Clubhouse bar and restaurant in Gullane, said: ldquoAs a local business, the Old Clubhouse is in no doubt about the positive economic impact of more cycling and walking infrastructure.ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has shown that people clearly want more active travel options.ldquoThat is why our business hopes East Lothian Council will look to the future and invest more in active travel infrastructure.A spokeswoman for the local authority stressed it ldquoremains committed to identying and securing active travel options in East Lothian, building upon previous projects.She said: ldquoWe have delivered a comprehensive path network across the county and, over the past five years, have committed capital funding to sustainable travel options, including the safe link from Gullane to North Berwick.ldquoWe are developing proposals for further projects around East Lothian, and having active travel at the core of local transport infrastructure will be a key priority going forward.ldquoWe are also preparing a bid for funding under the new infrastructure programme Spaces for People, which offers funding and support to councils in Scotland to make it safer for people to walk, cycle or wheel for essential trips and exercise during Covid- restrictions.

title: pipers-cook-storm-local-charity
story: Haddington Pipe Band has linked up with Our Community Kitchen, raising more than pound, to support the group, which is based in the townrsquos bowling club.Alastair Bruce, who is on the bandrsquos board of trustees, was delighted to help out in what were challenging circumstances for both organisations.He said: ldquoWe were obviously going to miss all the events that usually go on at this time of the year.ldquoWe came up with the idea of having performances in our gardens at the regular time of Saturday at noon and to keep playing and cheer folk up.ldquoWe started doing that and got a couple of weeks into it and were aware of what Our Community Kitchen were doing.ldquoWe wanted to support them and their fantastic work.The pipe band, which has been  and  members aged from nine to their s, would usually be performing at galas and civic celebrations throughout the county.However, the coronavirus has led to the cancellation of a number of those scheduled events, with weddings also being shelved due to the global pandemic.Mr Bruce said the pipe band decided to use their weekly performances as a fundraiser for Our Community Kitchen and set up an online fundraising page.An initial target of pound has been shattered, with the fundraising figure breaking through the pound, barrier.Mr Bruce thanked everyone that had donated to the cause and said: ldquoIt is wonderful.ldquoWe are really grateful to everybody that has helped with that.ldquoIt has not just been band members who have contributed but other people, who are aware of what the band are doing.ldquoOur Community Kitchen are really pleased as well and it helps them with their work as well.Our Community Kitchen was formed  months ago, with the aim of tackling social isolation in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward by getting people round the dinner table.However, the group was forced to change its method of addressing the problem when social gathering events were banned in March.Instead, they have delivered more than , piping hot meals, ranging from sausage, mash, stuffing and onion gravy to tuna macaroni and cheese, to people in their homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.Elaine Gale, founder of the group, who are delivering meals four times a week, was delighted with the pipe bandrsquos efforts and thanked them.She said: ldquoEvery Saturday, people play in their gardens or the street and where I live in Fairway, we have got two wonderful pipers and people donate.ldquoThey have raised more than pound,, which is unbelievable.ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled that they are doing that for Our Community Kitchen and we are doing our very best for the local community.ldquoIt is wonderful as well to hear them on a Saturday.ldquoI go out and listen to them and it just makes me feel really, really happy and quite tearful and emotional, to be honest.To support the pipe band and Our Community Kitchen, go to justgiving fundraising title: community-resilience-volunteers-dunbar-dunpender-haddington-gifford
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at four of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.DunbarFACE-TO-FACE counselling sessions are now being offered by The Ridge to people in need of advice or support as lockdown restrictions ease.The support service is able to see residents while respecting social distancing measures, and can offer help with citizensrsquo advice and mental health support.Dunbar community resilience teams are continuing their work to support the most vulnerable residents and those in isolation or need of help.George Robertson, who is at the heart of the resilience efforts, said the work by volunteers was much appreciated by the community.He said: ldquoOur volunteer teams continue to support the local community with the usual range of lsquogood neighbourrsquo services.ldquoThe foodbank and meals service continue to be busy and their efforts are very much appreciated by the community.ldquoThe Ridge are providing citizensrsquo advice and mental health support and are now able to offer face-to-face counselling with social distancing in one of their buildings.ldquoOur pet service had a couple of calls to take a dog to the vet and another to a grooming service.A campaign to provide refurbished laptops for schools has also been a success and George thanked everyone who has donated to it.He said: ldquoAfter a thorough clean, re-install and repair, these items are now being delivered to the Dunbar schools. Fteen laptops were delivered [last] Friday, and a further  on Monday.ldquoDonations are slowing down now, probably because most have been gathered.Anyone who still has a laptop or tablet they are willing to donate can get in touch with the Dunbar Covid Team at Dunbar.covid@gmail or by calling  .DunpenderTHE resilience effort in East Linton and surrounding villages is ldquokind of quiet and winding down a bit, says community council chairwoman Judith Priest, as more residents are able to leave home.And Dunpender Community Councilrsquos emergency response team will wind down once the Government declares lockdown over, said Judith.ldquoThis was an emergency response so we wonrsquot continue with it in this form, Judith said.ldquoWersquore looking at winding up at the end of July. But we hope to keep the resilience team mothballed, as it were, for future use, having set it up and had volunteers happy to have their names kept on a list.In the meantime, information relating to the coronavirus can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also contact   or  .HaddingtonTHINGS are getting much quieter in Haddington, though calls are still coming in, while the number of resilience team volunteers is shrinking, says Haddington Community Council vicechairman Chris McEwan.Emergency shopping has been completed for some residents, and the team has seen several more foodbank referrals, as workplaces remain closed and employees are struggling financially.The team is also continuing to perform prescription uplts for those who remain shielding.ldquoItrsquos becoming more dficult for us, as some of our volunteers are starting toto work themselves, said Chris.The resilience teamrsquos pool of volunteers is now ldquoseverely diminished, said Chris.ldquoWe had -odd volunteers and wersquore now a fraction of that.While referrals from the council have slowed down, the group continues to support residents with whom it has struck up a relationship, and who remain in need of assistance.The community council team is discussing when to wind down support.ldquoItrsquos all based on what the Scottish Governmentrsquos shielding targets are, said Chris.ldquoWersquore hoping East Lothian Council has a plan for this. The biggest problem we have now is the number of volunteers.Chris also pointed out the impact all the work during lockdown has had on the volunteers themselves.ldquoWersquove all been doing this since March, he said, ldquoa lot of us havenrsquot had a break since then, so therersquos that aspect ndash we need to keep the mental health of our volunteers up. My bad jokes are usually the biggest source of enjoyment!Anyone needing assistance can still visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   between am and pm.GfordTHE Gford Larder launched this week, to help support households in the community council area who are having dficulties accessing essential food and household items due to the financial impact of Covid-.The larder will operate by appointment only on Tuesdays and Fridays in Gford Village Hallrsquos Todrick Room.The appointments system will allow organisers to manage social distancing and numbers, as well as give people the privacy to attend in confidence.Adam White, Gfordrsquos resilience co-ordinator, said: ldquoWe were very kindly offered a private financial donation to establish a service for people living within our community council area.ldquoFirst we spent time researching similar schemes, most notably in Dirleton, to shape our thinking. It is important that whatever we do is of real help to people, is safe and is sustainable.ldquoWersquore very grateful to everyone who has helped us reach this stage, to our coordinators Julia and Katy, and our volunteers who will be operating the larder. We will be gathering feedback on the Gford Larder as it progresses.Organisers welcome support for the new service but are asking people not to donate food.They said: ldquoWe are not accepting food donations. This is because it adds another complex layer of organisation that would need to be managed ndash it is harder to offer certainty of what people using the service can expect to find and it is harder to manage stock control ndash we want to avoid waste.ldquoIt also means our co-ordinators can respond to what visitors are telling us they would benefit from. We have carried out research before making this decision and we hope you understand.Instead, people wanting to donate food are asked to consider East Lothian Foodbank, in Tranent, with Yester Church in the process of setting up a collection point.Gford Community Councilrsquos Facebook and website pages have been updated to include information on the new larder service, posters are being created and leaflets will be delivered to all homes in the area.To find out more, go to www.gfordvillage.org post the-gford-food-larderMeanwhile, additional supplies of face coverings have been handed into Hoggrsquos newsagent by local volunteers and crafters who have been busy sewing.All donations are used by the ldquoSoup and a Smile service volunteers, and the face coverings have been very well received by members of the community.Anyone who needs support or wants to help can contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or the Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.uk

title: couples-living-apart-scotland-can-sleepover-today----rules
story: As part of the countryrsquos move into Phase  in the route map out of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for an lsquoextended householdrsquo.She said the Scottish Government was mindful of the ldquowider harms that come from the restrictions put in place to tackle the coronavirus ndash including ldquoloneliness and isolation, particular for older people living alone and lone parents.And while the idea of an extended household has wide-ranging benefits, therersquos one aspect in particular, called by some as a ldquosex bubble, that has people talking.The new arrangements, permitted from today, means that non-cohabiting couples - where at least one of them lives alone - can be reunited indoors without social distancing for the first time in three months."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Scotland enters Phase  of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon confirms","description": "Lockdown restrictions are being eased further in Scotland, with people who live on their own or only with children under  able to form an  ucextended household group ud from Friday, Nicola Sturgeon has said.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media MlYzw poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests MlYzw.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": What can I do under an lsquoextended household rsquoWithin an extended household group, people will be able to meet indoors, without physical distancing and stay overnight - though onlythey wish.But they must continue to see any other households outdoors only, and stay more than  metres apart from them.Who can form one Only people who live alone, or who live only with children under -years-old, can form an extended household.The idea is it could allow, for example, a grandparent who lives on their own to form a group with another household in their family.It will allow a single parent and their children to join with another household for support.And, of course, couple who live apartcan be reunited and stay over.But, an important detail to note: people who are shielding CANNOT form an extended household.Can I have more than one extension No. A person should not form an extended household with more than one other household.Can I leave my lsquobubblersquo Yes, you can.Households can agree to end the arrangement at any time ndash but they should NOT then form a subsequent lsquobubblersquo with another household. So perhaps choose wisely.Whatsomeone in my lsquoextended householdrsquo gets coronavirus This is where it gets tricky.Put simply,one member of your extended household gets the virus, the entire group has to isolate.This is regardless of whether or not they are living in the same property.As an addition to that, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI would also encourage those who choose to form extended households to pay particular attention to hygiene measures ndash to reduce the risk that one household will bring the virus into another.When will this be extended to other groups of people The First Minister did not provide a date on when this could be extended to more people.But she added she will ldquoconsiderand to what extent we can expand it over the next few weeks, admitting it will not immediately make a dference to everyone.She urged the public to visit the Scottish Government website for more information, adding: ldquoWith the best will in the world, we cannot provide precise answers for every bespoke situation.ldquoSo when in doubt, use your judgement and err on the side of caution.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-cockenzie-port-seton-tranent-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at three of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonCOCKENZIE and Port Setonrsquos resilience team has now delivered more than , meals to residents in the community during lockdown.The meals are made at Port Seton Centre by East Lothian Council staff, assisted by resilience volunteers who also deliver them.The ,th meal was delivered to David Finlayson, who has been shielding, by council staff member Paul Brown, who is usually based in Longniddry Community Centre.Some of the villagersquos younger residents have also been offering their services as volunteers, with the time they spend volunteering with the resilience team going towards their Saltire Awards ndash the Scottish Governmentrsquos celebration of youth volunteers.Meanwhile, the list of services on offer to residents has grown in the past week.Volunteers are now cutting grass for those whose gardens need it and are delivering books to those on the library list who would usually borrow books regularly.The latter service is being run from Port Seton Library.Cockenzie and Port Setonrsquos resilience effort is being led by the local community council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, told the Courier that, alongside these new developments, everything  was ldquocarrying on as normal.The resilience group has also received donations from The Seaglass Inn and Seton Burns Club, with proceeds going towards and supporting its ongoing work.A food pantry is available at Port Seton Centre pm-pm, Monday-Friday, with delivery available by calling  .The hardship fund is also continuing, supporting those whose circumstances have changed and are in need of extra support.For more information, people are asked to email ebrown@eastlothian.gov.uk or to call the centre.Those who need assistance or help of any kind can call  .PrestonpansTHE Pennypit Pantry hit a milestone last week as it recorded , meals being made since it launched its support service in March.Prestonpans Community Council praised the team behind the project for its hard work during tough times.Brian Weddell, chairman, said: ldquoThe two driving forces at The Pennypit, Debbie Reynolds and Angie Davie, lead a hard-working team of dedicated staff supplemented by the resilience volunteers.ldquoEveryone involved with supporting people in the community has their ups and downs.ldquoWe get a huge amount of positive feedback from people receiving the support however, the downside is when someone we have been helping becomes ill or passes away.ldquoPeople we have all got to know well and built friendships with have lost family members, spouses and neighbours ndash but one thing they all say is how thankful and grateful they are for the staff they see every day and for the food packages.ldquoThe pantry has become much more than just a food provision ndash our volunteers are speaking to people who are lonely, building relationships and just being a familiar and friendly face.The community resilience team is preparing for the impact of the Scottish Government lsquotest and protectrsquo strategy which could see the number of people self-isolating increase.Families and people who can support themselves are urged to use a collection service, which is available from the Pennypit Pagoda, while following social distancing and the safety procedures in place.If anyone in Prestonpans is needing support with meals or essential groceries, the Pennypit Pantry can be contacted on   or by emailing lornabellany@gmailAs well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday Chicken Dinners are still being provided and last weekend they delivered  dinners.Sunday dinners can be ordered via the East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes page on Facebook or  .Prestonpans Community Council continues to offer a hardship fund for people finding it dficult as lockdown continues, and anyone needing support should telephone the resilience hotline number on   or email prestonpansresilience@gmail.TranentTHE resilience group in Tranent and Elphinstone will be reaching out to offer support to carers in the community who may be feeling isolated.The resilience group will then be able to respond and offer these carers someone to chat to and supportitrsquos needed.Meanwhile, the resilience effort continues and volunteers have been helping those in need, from picking up shopping and prescriptions, to post office visits, deliveries and dog walking.However, these types of requests have been slowing down and volunteers are now mostly helping with food production and deliveries.The resilience team in Tranent also assists Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with meal deliveries, and has been supporting the school hub and its meal and lunch deliveries.The effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council, overseen by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .Anyone who needs help can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIn Elphinstone, Roots and Fruits is helping lsquoTeam Elphyrsquo by delivering lunches to residents and supporting people in the village.Its community food larder, offering free produce, is available noon-.pm every day for anyone who needs it.Those who need support can contact Roots and Fruits on  .Roots and Fruits also received a donation of money from Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, which will be used to help fund and support this work.

title: racing-gets-green-light-return
story: Musselburgh Racecourse will stage the first of five meeting on the last day of the month with fixtures also planned for Wednesday, July .They will be followed by fixtures scheduled on Friday, July , Thursday, July , and Wednesday, August .The first race in Scotland since the Covid outbreaktakes place at Ayr this Monday .It is expected other fixtures will be assigned by the British Horseracing Authority in due course to Musselburgh and Scotlandrsquos other four racecourses.Musselburghrsquos management team hasestablished procedures for hosting controlled meetings without spectators which meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards and have been working closely with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland in preparation for the resumption of racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, welcomed the announcement and said Scottish racing was fully prepared to play a vital role in supporting owners, trainers and the wider horseracing sector.He said: ldquoControlled horseracing meetings have been very successfully introduced in England, Ireland and a number of other countries and we are looking forward to playing our part in getting the wheels of the industry turning again in Scotland.Racing fans will be able to follow the action through a number of dferent options, including live screening on Racing TV, ITV Racing, on catch up via Racing TV Player, and through bookmakers websites for those who have accounts.Joe FitzPatrickMSP, minister for public health,sport  wellbeing, said: ldquoIrsquom sure that this news will be welcomed by racing fans across the country. The resumption of professional sports is another step towards some level of normality and its safe resumption is only possible thanks to a constructive relationship between the Scottish Government and bodies like Scottish Racing.Delly Innes, manager of Scottish Racing, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome theof racing in Scotland after a long, but necessary, absence as Scotland faced the challenges of Covid-. This has been an immensely challenging time for our five excellent racecourses, but this is an important first step on the road to recovery, and we will be working hard to ensure all our participants are familiar with, and adhere to Scottish rules and guidance where these dfer from UK guidance.ldquoWe are raring to go with an exciting programme of fixtures in the months ahead which will help support the wider Scottish and British racing industry, and provide entertainment to viewers across the country.

title: lifeboat-called-assist-kayaker-distress
story: The crew was paged at .am by the Coastguard after the kayaker had fallen into the water while fishing half a mile off shore.The all weather leboat was launched from nearby Torness Power Station at .am.Two crew members were on board and set off to try and locate the man.They received help from a passing angler who had spotted him clinging to his boat, they then rescued the man and helped him aboard the leboat.The crew ed to the shore and helped the man reach coastguard teams from Dunbar and North Berwick.The man was said to be extremely cold and shivery and was then assessed by paramedics, he appeared to otherwise be uninjured.The leboat crew then helped recover the manrsquos kayak and at am were stood down by the Coastguard.A Dunbar RNLI spokesman said: ldquoAlthough the kayaker was well-equipped he had been in the water for sometime and was initially reluctant to call for help. We would urge anyone in dficulty in or near the water to call  and ask for the Coastguard.As Scotland moves into phase two of easing lockdown restrictions, Dunbar RNLI urged that boat users be prepared before ing to the water.As boats have been sitting idle for the past few months people are asked to make sure they have good, fresh fuel in the tank and that water and oil are at the correct levels.People are asked to check weather forecasts and sea conditions before setting off and to always wear a lejacket, should a person fall into the water unexpectedly they are four times more likely to survivewearing one.They are also asked to carry a means to call for help and to not put themselves, their family or the emergency services at risk.

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsman that it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

title: roadworks-close-part-a1
story: The eastbound carriageway between the Gladsmuir junction and Oaktree junction, near Haddington, will be closed from pm tomorrow until am on Thursdaywhile work is carried out.A ersion will be put in place and signposted, taking people via the B, A through Gladsmuirand then onto the B into Haddington.The following night , the westbound carriageway will be closed from Gladsmuir to the Bankton junction, north of Tranent,from pm on Thursday night until am on Friday morning .A ersion will take people on the A, which passes through Tranent.The works, which are described by operating company Amey as ldquoessential, are estimated to cost about pound,.Amey said the work will ldquoimprove safety and reduce overall maintenance costs by mitigating the need for further reactive repairs.Work is being completed by a contractor on behalf of Amey and Transport Scotland.While the work is being carried out, physical distancing will be in place to ensure all staff on site remain safe.Thorough risk assessments will be carried out and cleansing stations will also be put in place on site.For more information visit scottishtrunkroadsse-live.amey a overnight-roadworks-on-the-a--juneor East Lothian Councils website and Facebook page.

title: 1-650-spent-remind-residents-keep-distance
story: The ft-high information boards have been produced to remind people to follow social distancing rules as restrictions on outdoor gatherings are eased.With the message Keep East Lothian Moving, the boards remind people to maintain a two-metre distance and "consider others when youre out and about".The messages are accompanied by images of people out walking their dogs, with their families, running and cycling and an elderly person using a walking aid, as well as a skateboarder.East Lothian Council said it had invested more than pound, in the boards which will appear across  key sites.The move comes as the local authority also deployed mobile electronic signs on the A coast road over the weekend reminding people to stay local.The electronic signs, usually used to deter speeding on the road, changed its message as the council reopened its larger coastal car parks for local residents to use.They warned people not to stray too far from their home comforts with the message, Stay Local No Public Toilets.A council spokesperson said the new social distance boards would be placed at sites around the county.They said: ldquoAt this stage, we have identied  locations in dferent parts of East Lothian where these materials, highlighting the importance of physical distancing guidelines, will be put in place."Thirty copies have been ordered at a cost of pound,.

title: losing-sense-smell-coronavirus---happens
story: FROM the first reports coming out of Wuhan, Iran and later Italy, we knew that losing your sense of smellwas a signicant symptom of the disease.Now, after months of reports, both anecdotal and more rigorous clinical findings, we think we have a model for how this virus may cause smell loss.One of the most common causes of smell loss is a viral infection, such as the common cold, sinus or other upper respiratory tract infections.Those coronaviruses that donrsquot cause deadly diseases, such as COVID-, Sars and Mers, are one of the causes of the common cold and have been known to cause smell loss.In most of these cases, sense of smell s when symptoms clear, as smell loss is simply the result of a blocked nose, which prevents aroma molecules reaching olfactory receptors in the nose. In some cases, smell loss can persist for months and years.For the novel coronavirus , however, the pattern of smell loss is dferent. Many people with COVID- reported a sudden loss of sense of smell and then a sudden and fullto a normal sense of smell in a week or two.Interestingly, many of these people said their nose was clear, so smell loss cannot be attributed to a blocked nose.For others, smell loss was prolonged and several weeks later they still had no sense of smell. Any theory of anosmia in COVID- has to account for both of these patterns.This suddenof a normal sense of smell suggests an obstructive smell loss in which the aroma molecules cannot reach the receptors in the nose .Now that we have CT scans of the noses and sinuses of people with COVID- smell loss, we can see that the part of the nose that does the smelling, the olfactory cleft, is blocked with swollen soft tissue and mucus ndash known as a cleft syndrome.The rest of the nose and sinuses look normal and patients have no problem breathing through their nose.We know that the way SARS-CoV- infects the body is by attaching to ACE receptors on the surface of cells that line the upper respiratory tract.A protein called TMPRSS then helps the virus invade the cell. Once inside the cell, the virus can replicate, triggering the immune systemrsquos inflammatory response. This is the starting point for the havoc and destruction that this virus causes once in the body.Initially, we thought that the virus might be infecting and destroying the olfactory neurons.These are the cells that transmit the signal from the aroma molecule in your nose to the area in the brain where these signals get interpreted as ldquosmell.However, an international collaboration showed recently that the ACE proteins the virus needs to invade the cells were not found on the olfactory neurons.But they were found on cells called ldquosustentacular cells, which support the olfactory neurons.We expect that these support cells are likely to be the ones that are damaged by the virus, and the immune response would cause swelling of the area but leave the olfactory neurons intact.When the immune system has dealt with the virus, the swelling subsides and the aroma molecules have a clear route to their undamaged receptors and the sense of smell s to normal.So why does smell notin some cases This is more theoretical but follows from what we know about inflammation in other systems.Inflammation is the bodyrsquos response to damage and results in the release of chemicals that destroy the tissues involved.When this inflammation is severe, other nearby cells start to be damaged or destroyed by this ldquosplash damage. We believe that accounts for the second stage, where the olfactory neurons are damaged.Recovery of smell is much slower because the olfactory neurons need time to regenerate from the supply of stem cells within the lining of the nose.Initial recovery is often associated with distortion of the sense of smell known as parosmia, where things donrsquot smell like they used to.For many parosmics, for instance, the smell of coffee is often described as burnt, chemical, dirty and reminiscent of sewage.Physiotherapy for the noseOlfaction has been called the Cinderella of the senses because of its neglect by scientic research.But it has come to the forefront in this pandemic. The silver lining is that we will learn a lot about how viruses are involved in smell loss from this. But what hope is there for people with a loss of smell now The good news is that the olfactory neurons can regenerate. Theyrsquore regrowing in almost all of us, all of the time. We can harness that regeneration and guide it with ldquophysiotherapy for the nose: smell training.

title: headteacher-praised-leadership-style
story: North Berwick High Schools head Lauren Rodgers was described by Education Scotland inspectors as having a clear direction and being well respected.However while the inspection, carried out in February,praised the staff and leadership at the school and achievements of its senior students, it pointed to improvements required to enable more S-S pupils to learn a foreign language.The report called for more work to be done to ensure all younger students received their full entitlement to Broad General Educationin the first three years at the school.In particular it stated: "Currently, a few young people are not experiencing a modern language until the end of S."Inaddition, the current arrangement is not sufficient for young people to receive their entitlementto a meaningful experience of a third language."Inspectors urged the school to ensure the focus was on ensuring younger pupils received full access to experiences across the curriculum and did not allow a focus on reaching exam levels to impact on them.The inspectors said: "Teachers should ensure that learning at Sacross all curriculum areas remains focused on the experiences and outcomes of CfEanddoes not prioritise the requirements of National Qualications ."Senior and middle leadersshould ensure that learning experiences in S provide those young people specialising atfourth level with appropriate depth in their learning to provide successful progression to thesenior phase."Inspectors visited the school in February  and assessed the schoolrsquos performance across four key indicators: leadership of change learning, teaching and assessment raising attainment and achievement and ensuring wellbeing, equality and inclusion.The school was evaluated as lsquovery goodrsquo in the first three categories and lsquogoodrsquo in the fourth.Headteacher Lauren Rodgerrsquos leadership style was described as ldquocharacterised by openness and by trust, promoting empowerment in a supportive ethos. Inspectors highlighted the strong leadership at all staff levels and the use of effective research to support creative learning.Innovative approaches to teaching and assessment encourage young people to take responsibility for their own learning. Where young people are facing personal challenges, the report noted that targeted strategies are used to support them, and an open climate exists within the school around mental health.As part of the process, inspectors make recommendations for areas of improvement. The letter outlines recommendations that the school continues with its improvements to the planning process for S-S and reviews its approaches for checking on pupilrsquos wellbeing.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councils cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate Lauren Rodger and her team on a very positive report. The inspectorsrsquo comments regarding strong leadership and how this supports pupilsrsquo attainment through creative learning and personal responsibility is a real testament to the school teamrsquos positive work and ethos."Thisreport will provide confidence and comfort for parents and carers, and is much-welcomed good news for the school community.Lesley Brown, chief operating officer for education at the local authority, said: ldquoIrsquom sure this report will be welcomed by everyone connected with North Berwick High School."Irsquom especially pleased to see inspectors recognise the work that staff and pupils have undertaken to open-up conversations around mental health and wellbeing."This will be especially important in the months ahead as weto school, and is very much in line with our approach to use nurture to help reconnect and recover from Covid. Irsquod like to commend Lauren Rodger and her team on their achievements and their commitment to creating such strong learning opportunities.

title: staycation-five-scotlands-photogenic-places-visit-lockdown-eases
story: After exactly three months of lockdown things are starting to look up ndash and just last week it was revealed Scotlandrsquos tourism sector ndash including hotels, pubs and restaurants ndash could reopen from July .And with our beautul scenery, immersing history and friendly locals, therersquos no wonder why some research shows more than half of Brits are eyeing up a lsquostaycationrsquo this year rather than opting to go abroad.With that in mind, wersquove detailed outfiveof the most photogenic lsquostaycationrsquo locations to visit in Scotland once lockdown measures are eased.Harris, Outer HebridesWhen thinking about a lsquostaycationrsquo in Scotland, itrsquos understandable that a beach holiday isnrsquot the first thing on your mind.But the Outer Hebrides beaches are some of the most beautul in Europe ndash and it would be hard to blame youyou thought it was somewhere in the Caribbeanhellip perhaps only the temperature would give it away.In March, Luskentyre Bay on Harris was named as one of the top  beaches in the world by Tripadvisor.The far-flung, sandy outpost - which is reached by a single track road - was rated higher than sun-soaked destinations in Spain, the Caribbean, and the golden shores of Florida to take th spot in the prestigious s Travellers Choice Awards.Described by the sites visitors "as close to heaven as you could get", the expanse of Luskentyre Bay sits on the South of Harris, close to the isolated island of Taransay, where the seminal BBC reality series Castaway  was filmed.Tobermory, MullIt doesnrsquot take a tourism expert to identy the colourful harbour-front buildings of Tobermory from the popular childrenrsquos TV show Balamory.The capital of Mull, Tobermory is arguably one of the prettiest ports in Scotland thanks to the before-mentioned colourful houses and sheltered bay.Legend has it that Tobermory was the location of the sinking of Spanish Armada ship in , carrying gold bullion.You can find out all about the history of the area in the Mull museum ndash orgolf is more of your fancy then therersquos a nine-hole course sitting in the clfs above the bay.The ldquotough challenge offers panoramic views across to the Ardnamurchan Peninsula and, on a clear day, the Isle of Skye.The bay is also a departure point for whale watching and wildle cruises.Eilean Donan, HighlandsItrsquos the most photographed castle in Scotland and has been featured in blockbuster films including James Bond.Recognised around the world as one of the most iconic images of Scotland, itrsquos little wonder the castle is now one of the most visited attractions in the Scottish Highlands.Strategically located on its own little island overlooking the isle of Skye, the castle sits where three lochs ndash Loch Duich, Loch Long and Loch Alsh meet.Surrounded by the mountains of Kintail, visitors have the chance to wander around the internal rooms of the castle while also taking in the wonderful wildle that surrounds the island too ndash with porpoise, dolphins, otters and birdle sightings an often occurrence.Arran, North AyrshireThe Isle of Arran is often described as ldquoScotland in Miniature, soyoursquore looking for a quick staycation but with a lot to experience then look no further.The ever-changing coastline, dramatic mountain peaks, sheltered beaches and tasty local produce makes a holiday in Arran unforgettable.Donrsquot forget to pack your camera ndash with the stunning views of and from the islandrsquos largest mountain, Goatfell, worth capturing.Not only that but the island boasts a wealth of nature, including red squirrels, deer, golden eagles, otters, seals and basking sharks just waiting to be snapped up.Glenfinnan Viaduct, HighlandsMade ever more popular by the Harry Potter films, the Glenfinnan Viaduct attracts thousands of visitors from across the world every year.The special atmosphere and the stunning scenery overlooking the famous railway track makes for some magical images ndash no wonder why they chose it for the wizarding films.The famous viaduct carries the railway to Glenfinnan station across a ft span, ft above the ground ndash and the Jacobite steam train runs from here to Fort William and Mallaig in the summer months.Visitors are reminded, however, that trespassing on the railway line is extremely dangerous and they should stay clear of the tracks at all times.Full details of all the locations and more are available on Visit Scotlands website here.And remember: Do not travel for leisure until the Scottish Government guidance says it is acceptable to do so.

store leases.He will hope to save as many as  stores and , jobs.The firm announced the news in June.:Monsoon enters administration threatening over  job lossesQuizCity locations:Buchanan Street, St  staff affected by the decision will remain with the group but that  jobs are at risk.Quiz will look to buy back the stock and some of the assets from the Kast ision placed in administration for title: Country Life with Rosemary Goring  Away with the birds
story: It seems that spending spring and early summer in lockdown has turned the country into a nation of bird lovers. Itrsquos not just in the countryside that they have become a large part of our lives, a source of ersion, fascination and even, or so I have felt, of company. Stepping outside in the morning is like entering the Usher Hall during warm-up, a discordant and energetic orchestra of flutes, pipes and trumpets. As I brush my teeth, I sometimes see Wilf, the blackbird with the silver ankle ring, by the chimney, letting the wind ruffle his feathers. He has a very keen look, and when our eyes meet, you feel you have been noted. By evening, his spot is taken by a pair of turtle doves which perch side by side on the TV aerial, well camouflaged against the dusky sky.Alan saw Wilf enjoying a bath in a puddle the other day, near his HQ, in the centre of the village. On our first social gathering in months ndash a glass of wine in a neighbourrsquos garden one warm evening ndash Wilf landed on the lawn beside us, hopping behind our chairs, and unperturbed by our friendsrsquo inquisitive dog. Clearly he considers every garden to be his private food department. Theirs is Fortnum and Mason to our Lidl.A barn owl has been seen in the village lately, out hunting before dark. The photos show a beautul, ghostly creature with a heart-shaped pale face, after which Hoolet is named. It was gliding low between trees and across the edge of rough fields. I hope it kept its distance from the blue tits, because other birdsrsquo chicks are the perfect snack for owls and their owlets. That comes as little surprise, but it wasnrsquot till recently that I learned that the woodpeckers haunting our garden might be lingering near the nestbox in hope of a tasty snack. A large one had taken up position on the gatepost, a few days ago, within earshot of the nest. Squirrels, meanwhile, are the stuff of blue titsrsquo horror movies. They have been known to gnaw away at a nestbox entrance to reach the birds inside.The charm most of us find in bird le and nature is often a rose-tinted perspective. For birds, every day is a challenge, a survival exercise tougher than anything the SAS could conceive. Often Irsquoll see the older blue tits, decidedly dishevelled, stuffing themselves on our peanut feeders as they boost their blood sugar levels ahead of another caterpillar hunt. Occasionally a scattering of feathers in the flowerbeds indicate where a cat has brought down a weary or unwary bird. The RSPB says that the avian massacre by cats ndash estimated to be over  million a year ndash is a natural winnowing, with only the weak or ill falling prey. Irsquom not convinced. It sounds like a half-truth, aimed to prevent all-out conflict between bird and feline lovers. Not that the two are mutually exclusive.Danger is all around,yoursquore small and feathered. Friends were out for a walk beyond Hoolet recently, and spotted a flock of sparrows, feeding on grass-heads. Suddenly, not six feet away from them, a sparrowhawk swooped and snatched one of the birds. The speed of the attack, and the hawkrsquos audacity, were startling.Nor was this a first sighting of this turbo-charged predator that moves at the speed of a bullet. Occasionally I catch one ing between our house and a neighbourrsquos garden. As it flashes past the kitchen window, you know this is no idle reconnaissance. From its perch high in the sycamore, it has spied something delicious. The best you can hope is that, for the creature caught in its crosswires, the end is mercully swt.With less traffic, you see far fewer birds flattened on the roads, especially pheasants, which usually seem positively eager to examine the chassis of approaching cars. Our neighbours were nevertheless worried that theyrsquod found a pegged-out pheasant among their poppies. Hearing them calling to us through the beech hedge ndash by now almost as impenetrable as the Berlin Wall ndash we hurried over to offer first-aidrequired.The glittering, fearless ndash and pea-brained  ndash beauty, which has been parading our gardens since springtime, was far from dead. It had simply settled itself into an earthy dip to enjoy the sun. This would explain the dusty hollows Irsquove been finding of late in the shrubbery, asan easter egg-sized UFO had landed. Unfazed by the humans clucking anxiously around it, the pheasant only roused itself and got to its feet when it heard us approaching on the gravel.Another frequent visitor is the young hedgehog which has taken to walking up the road to the house, around tea-time, and disappearing into the back garden. Seeing it approach, I stuck my head out of the door into the pouring rain, and noticed it has a limp. Seen from behind, it lurched on one hind leg, like a trolley with a wonky wheel. Since it was going at a lick, and obviously knew exactly where it was heading, I left it to get on with it.Itrsquos a matter of days before the blue tits will be out of their nest, and bouncing around the garden. In a second-hand bookshop last year I found a guide to making your garden more bird friendly. In a chapter on building nestboxes for dferent species, it advised that, after the breeding season, these boxes must be cleaned, to protect future broods from disease. This must be how landlords feel when the end of a tenancy is approaching. The need to disinfect is clearly universal. Unique to providers of avian accommodation, however, is the warning to brace yourselves for finding addled eggs, or the remains of chicks that failed to thrive. You can be sure this task will fall to me.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: POLITICS WATCH  Talking heads know when to stay quiet
story: The first series of monologues aired in  when the coat of one Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, was on a shoogly peg.When the next series came along a decade later, there was a newbie premier called Tony Blair in Downing Street.Here we are, , and another PM, Boris Johnson, is in office, future unknown, despite that thumping majority. His immediate task  The further easing of the lockdown in England without causing a surge in new cases.Ahead of the main act announcing something this week, Downing Street sent a warm-up man in the shape of Englandrsquos Health Secretary, Matt Hancock. On the dove-ish side of the lockdown easing debate, he was perhaps better placed than some to reassure the public that it would be safe to get back out there into pubs, restaurants, and schools.Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday was first to run the rule over the numbers with Mr Hancock. By presenter Sophy Ridgersquos reckoning, the contact tracers were only reaching two people a week.: Revolutionary vision for post-Covid ScotlandFar from being a sign of failure, said the Minister, this was a good thing. It showed there was spare capacity in the system, and that was because the number of new cases was falling.So to the much hyped app, meant to be the jewel at the centre of what the PM promised would be a ldquoworld-beating system of track and trace. With the failure of the Isle of Wight trial and still no date as to when the software will appear, the app has become a Bennettian ldquochip in the sugar, a sign of standards not being met and promises unfulfilled.Asked when the app would be ready, Mr Hancock said he was not going to put a date on it . ldquoIrsquom highly confident it will happen, said the Minister. By the time he reached The Andrew Marr Show this had become ldquoWersquoll get there with the app.Nick Robinson was standing in for Andrew Marr, whose father has died. The Today presenter was among those who deputised for the Scot after his stroke in . Robinson would have found the format much the same: start with the papers, end with a Minister, and pause in the middle for something lighter, in this case interviews with Kristen Scott Thomas, who stars in one of the Talking Heads, ldquoThe Hand of God, and Nicholas Hytner, who directs three of them.One major change Robinson could not have predicted are the by now regular slots on Marr for experts. Both Professor Sir Ian Diamond, the UKrsquos National Statistician, and Professor Peter Piot, director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine stressed that coronavirus had not gone away and there was no room for complacency.Professor Piot, described in his introduction as something of a star in the fight against viruses ndash the ldquoMick Jagger of microbes someone had called him ndash said he would be okay with a relaxation of the two metre rule as long as masks were worn in public places. He also called the quarantining of people entering the UK ldquouseless and urged the UK Government to appoint a Covid- tsar at Cabinet level.: Former FMslates blended learningIn all his answers he was as clear as day, unlike Mr Hancock who had to do the usual thankless ministerial task of talking about a subject while not giving anything away before the official announcement.In lieu of detail Mr Hancock had come bearing a new word: ldquomitigations. Besides mask wearing this appeared to include adopting the New Zealand system of asking people for contact information when they go to a pub or restaurant. Expect ldquosign here for a pint headlines in England.Robinson was not going to let Mr Hancock go without bringing up the Ministerrsquos breach of the social distancing rules, as caught on camera last week when he patted a colleague on the back in the Commons. ldquoIt was just totally natural, said Mr Hancock. ldquoThis shows how dficult social distancing is. All I can do is say Irsquom incredibly sorry for this momentary breach. Itrsquos because Irsquom human. Wersquore all human. It sounded like another headline in the making.One person determined not to make the headlines was Iain Stewart, the new Scotland Office Minister, making his first appearance on Politics Scotland.Mr Stewart, the MP for Milton Keynes South, got his job because the previous incumbent had resigned over Dominic Cummingsrsquo dash to Durham. But Mr Stewart had little to nothing to say on that to host Gordon Brewer. Nor was he keen to share his thoughts on extending the furlough in Scotland save for telling the Scottish Government to be ldquomore ambitious on reviving the economy.ldquoAll yoursquore doing is telling us things we already know, said Brewer. Mr Stewart was still not for budging. He survived his baptism of fire, or baptism of Brewer, by sticking ruthlessly to his lines. Anyone would think he fancied a part in the next run of Talking Heads.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.News from trusted and credible sources is essential at all times, but especially now as the coronavirus pandemic impacts on all aspects of our lives. To make sure you stay informed during this dficult time our coverage of the crisis is free.However, producing The Heralds unrivalled analysis, insight and opinion on a daily basis still costs money and, as our traditional revenue streams collapse, we need your support to sustain our quality journalism.To help us get through this, wersquore asking readers to take a digital subscription to The Herald. You can sign up now for just pound for two months.If you choose to sign up, wersquoll offer a faster loading, advert-light experience ndash and deliver a digital version of the print product to your device every day. title: letters-eis-working-hard-come-best-solutions-scotlands-schools
story: As a member of the Education Recovery Group, the EIS, Scotlandrsquos largest education union, has sought to engage constructively with partners, including national and local government, about how we can best deliver for Scotlandrsquos students. It was an EIS survey of more than , teachers which first highlighted the negative impact of lockdown on our most disadvantaged pupils and the scale of the digital ide it was the EIS which raised the scandal of unemployed newly-qualied teacherswhen our schools need more teachers it was the EIS which called for an equity audit and for resources to be made available to mentor and tutor inidual students hit hardest by deprivation at a local level it has been the EIS which has driven the risk assessments necessary to make our schools safe places, for pupils and staff, when they re-open come August.And over this past week, as Scottish politics ed to its ldquonormal bickering worst, it has been the EIS which has called for a national effort to ensure that the money is found to deliver the teachers and resources needed for a sustained education recovery effort ndash an effort in which both the EIS and its members are keen to play a role.Larry Flanagan, General Secretary, Educational institute of Scotland, Edinburgh EH.AM I missing something  How is "blended learning" going to benefit the hard-working teaching profession  So far as I can see, it will mean doubling their workload and halving the amount of education the children will receive ndash is this what our once-lauded education system has come to My mother was teaching in the s and s in the east end of Glasgow ndash large classes of -, without the aid of a classroom assistant and extra special needs funding. It was her proud claim that not one of her children left without being able to read and write. Coincidentally, it seemed that the majority of them wanted to learn, teachers and parents were respected and discipline was applied rigorously, despite the widespread poverty.I find it dficult to understand why, in our modern system of free education, more and more children seem to prefer to roam the streets, rather than apply themselves to learning the basic Rs. Interestingly, the children of immigrants seem to appreciate this more than our home-grown lot.I wonder why this would be Carol MacDonald, Troon.POLITICIANS and high-ranking civil servants behind the decision for "blended" schooling, aka part-time school, are largely cushioned from the consequences of their decisions: they dont have to choose between working and educating their children at home because they have jobs where they can be flexible about hours, can afford for their partners not to work full-time, can afford private tutors or to send their children to private schools whichthey are not offering full-time schooling in August will still be offering much more than state schools.But it isnt just the children of politicians and high-ranking civil servants who are protected from the consequences of their decisions about lockdown. They, together with the scientists who are advising them, are not facing redundancy. Very many people employed in hospitality, retail and many other businesses in the private sector will lose their livelihoods as this protracted lockdown pans out these senior figures in the public sector wont.Linda Holt , Anstruther.WHEN I retired from teaching almost  years ago it was obvious that a signicant proportion of my colleagues did not enjoy the best of health. Sadly, I gather that is still the case in the teaching profession and I wonder how willing those pressing the First Minister to instantlyto pre-Covid-style education would be to accept responsibility for the teacher deaths and serious illness that might follow such a policy Teachers are not the most popular people on the planet, but they are not easily replaceable either. The current crisis could harm the education of our youth in more than one way.Ronald Cameron , Fort William.Read more: Newly qualied teachers offer help to blended learning model amid SNP fury at Scottish Government plans

title: coronavirus-one-covid-case-detected-every-200-tests-scotland
story: The ratio of positive to negative test results indicates that Scotland ldquois on the safe side in terms of controlling the pandemic, according to a scientic briefing paper that draws comparisons with the performance in New Zealand and South Korea.It has also plunged since April, when more than one in five tests were coming back positive.It came as Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that no deaths from Covid had been reported in Scotland for a second day in a row, with just  confirmed or suspected Covid patients in intensive care.: Is Scotlands slow and steady exit from lockdown already working The First Minister said the progress would enable her to give ldquomore clarity later this week on a timeline for the next steps out of lockdown.For the first time, data covering the results from both NHS Scotland labs - which mainly process tests for hospital patients - and the UK Government-funded mobile and drive-thru testing centres has been made available online.It shows that a total of , tests were processed in Scotland last week - June  to  - from which  cases of Covid were detected.That positive case rate of . per cent compares to .% between April  to  when , positive Covid cases were picked up from a total of , NHS labtests.Although drive-thru testing numbers are recorded from April  - totalling  tests in that first week - positive results from those sites have only been included in the total since June .Across the UK as a whole, around .% of Covid tests are finding a positive case.That compares to around .% in the US, and .% in Italy.According to a background paper dated April  and drawn up by the UK Governmentrsquos scientic advisors to inform moves to a Test, Trace and Isolate Strategy - but also considered by the Scottish Governmentrsquos Covid Advisory Group - the percentage of positive Covid tests in a total sample is an important way of gauging the magnitude of the virus problem.The paper adopted Germanyrsquos criteria, which says thatmore than % of your virus tests are producing a positive result you ldquohave a problem.At less than %, the country is ldquogetting a handle on the problem and at around % ldquoyou are likely to be in control.By the time the positive rate falls to around % or less ldquoyou are on the safe side, said the paper, noting that this was the benchmark set early in the pandemic by Covid success stories such as Taiwan, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand.Fundamentally, the percentage positive rate is considered to be an important thermometer of whether a countrys testing regime is adequate to cope with the amount of virus spreading within its population.The World Health Organization recommends that the rate should be below % for at least two weeks before countries begin to relax social distancing and other public health measures.At the height of its Covid crisis, New York City had a positivity rate of % - a sign not only that it was the epicentre of the US outbreak, but also that the volume of testing was falling far short of what was needed."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Sturgeon reiterates need to be cautious to avoid coronavirus second wave","description": "Sturgeon reiterates need to be cautious to avoid coronavirus second wave","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media DyxEfCQ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests DyxEfCQ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": : Social care workers more than twice as likely to die from Covid as frontline NHS staffHowever, even a test positivity rate of % - as Scotland had in April - is still considered very high by infectious disease experts, and a sign that testing is skewed towards hospitals and likely to be missing huge numbers of mild or asymptomatic cases in the community who are still able to pass it on.Academics who compile daily Covid statistics for the website, Our World in Data, have highlighted the signicance of driving down the percentage positive rate.They wrote: "One important way to understandcountries are testing sufficiently is to ask: how many tests does a country do to find one Covid- case "We see enormous dferences across countries."Some countries, like Australia, South Korea and Slovenia do hundreds, or even thousands of tests for each case they find."Others, such as Mexico and Nigeria, only do a handful of tests ndash five or fewer ndash for every confirmed case."Countries that do very few tests per confirmed case are unlikely to be testing widely enough to find all cases."The WHO has suggested around -  tests per confirmed case as a general benchmark of adequate testing.": Family fear they could have been among the first to bring Covid to Scotland after Italian ski holidayAt yesterdays press briefing, Ms Sturgeon confirmed that  new Covid cases had been identied in Scotland as a result of  NHS lab tests and  tests at drive-thru and mobile sites.There are  patients with confirmed or suspected Covid in ICU, down from a peak of  on April , and a total of  confirmed cases in hospital - compared to  on April .Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoOur progress does allow us to consider now whether and to what extent we can give more clarity in terms of indicative dates for the next steps in our routemap out of lockdown.She said she will set out more detail on this later in the week. Hairdressers and cinemas are expected to re-open in July but no date has yet been given, and there has been no clear timetable for when relatives can begin visiting loved ones in care homes again.Phase  guidance, revised last week, simply states that "consideration [is] to be given to a phased resumption of visiting to care homes starting with outdoor facilities where it is clinically safe to do so".Diagnostic tests such as CT scans and endoscopies are to gradually resume, prioritised by clinical need, from Monday.However, Ms Sturgeon stressed the virus "hasnt gone away" as she pointed to recent outbreaks in Beijing and Germany, where  workers at a meat processing plant in Guetersloh have tested positive. The outbreak has pushed Germanys R number back up to ..Meanwhile, South Korean health officials say they are battling a "second wave" following a string of clusters linked to nightclubs, office buildings and warehouses. The mayor of Seoul said strict social distancing could be reinstated this week.ldquoI know that when deaths and cases here are continuing to fall, itrsquos very tempting for all of us to think itrsquos all over and we should just quickly get back to normal," said Ms Sturgeon."We want to do that as quickly as possible, but let me reiterate my strong view that moving recklessly now would be a serious mistake.

title: nine-hours-week-class-pupils-scotlands-best-performing-schools
story: Letters sent to parents of schools overseen by East Dunbartonshire Council show that secondary schools will only be able to accommodate nine pupils in every classroom - drastically cutting the amount of in-class time children will have.And primary schoolpupils will be in-school for two days a week, with home learning for two days as long as the two-metre social distancing rule to stop the spread of Covid- is in place.:Two thirds of Scots parents complain about having no online lessons from schools during lockdownIt comes as education secretary John Swinney prepares to make a statement on Tuesday at Holyrood on the next steps towards reopening schools.Pupils are due tofromAugust , but will initially have a "blended" approach involving face-to-face teaching and at-home learning.There has been speculationexams in  could be delayedand that blended learning could last for a year.TheHerald revealed the concerns of parents over future plans for childrens school as new analysis revealed two thirds of parents complained their school was not providing online lessons during the coronavirus lockdown.A parent poll raised concerns about a lack of face-to-face school time off the back of the Scottish Governments controversial blended learning plans when schools open again in August.East Dunbartonshire Council which looks after top performing secondary schools such as Douglas Academy, Bearsden Academy, Lenzie Academy, St Ninians High and Bishopbriggs Academy revealed its back to school information in a letter from chief education officer Jacqui MacDonald.She said that after an extensive exercise to assess the capacity of each secondary school, it was confirmed a maximum of nine pupils could be accommodated in each classroom of most schools.Following consultation with head teachers and unions, it was decided that all secondary schools in the council area would plan for one third of the year group attending at any one time - equating to nine hours in-class for each pupil.For primary school pupils this meant two-days, or  hours of in-school provision operating on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.""We understand that it is a very dficult time for parents, particularly those who need toto work, as children will not be in school full time," said the education chief, saying the focus was on "health and well-being".She added: "We are working to put in place additional childcare for the children of key workers. However this will be more limited than during lockdown as school buildings and our education staff will be needed to provide the in-school provision and home learning support during the week. We would ask parents to explore all possible options before applying for a key worker childcare place."Mr Swinney indicated a move to get local authorities to use other council spaces, even church halls to accommodate pupils.But Ms MacDonald said spaces within the school as well as other in the local area would have needed "signicant adaptation to create an appropriate nurturing environment for high quality learning and teaching in small groups".She added: "Accommodation out with the school would require to be risk assessed, with concerns including access to toilets and transport as well as adequate supervision and staffing."Staffing was also a "signicant constraint" with dficulties in recruiting teachers at a time when other schools were also seeking more staffing as a result of the new blended learning move. She also anticipated that there will be a number of staff "who may not be able to be in-school in August due to Covid-".She said there were plans to develop a Virtual School, across all secondaries to provide support for the home learning element, particularly those in S to S."This will support the development of home learning taking account of feedback from staff, pupils and parents," she said "Our aim is to provide the maximum time possible for children in-school but this is dependent on the guidance from Scottish Government and the compliance with all health and safety requirements due to Covid-."The news was greeted with concern from some parents.One said: "I was already concerned about the lack of educational support my children were getting from the school during lockdown. This does not allay those worries, and lays further questions as to how on earth working parents like myself are going to be able to cope with all this home schooling."The council was approached for comment.

title: pandemic-forces-three-sisters-bake-close-two-cafes
story: The owners of the Three Sisters Bake said it had been a "horribly hard decision" not to re-open atQuarriers Village in Kilmacolm and inKillearn but was taken in order to help sustain thebusiness in the aftermath of the pandemic.The siblings who run Three Sisters,Linsay, Nichola and Gillian Reith, said efforts will be focussed on theirweddings business,takeaway Cake Bar in Glasgows West End and online shop.The sisters launched a cookbook four years ago and Nichola was chosen to front BBC baking show Flour Power, which seesworkmate across Scotland battle for the cake-making crown.: Scottish Tourism facing precarious journey out of lockdownIn an online statement the business said: "As the lockdown measures that closed the hospitality industry are eased, circumstances have reshaped our family business."Unfortunately, as we refocus on these parts of our business, wersquove taken the dficult decision not to reopen our cafes at Quarriers Village and Killearn Village Hall."This has been a horribly hard decision but is the best option available to us at this time as we pivot the business in the aftermath of the pandemic.: Scottish campervan firm cites staycation potential as it s to production"We are looking forward to being able to hold our first post lockdown weddings and are continuing to take new bookings for  and ."Our wedding business, based at Killearn Village Hall as well as offsite wedding catering and wedding cakes will remain at the heart of Three Sisters Bake."We will continue to develop our takeaway shopCake Barin Glasgowrsquos West End on Great Western Road."Wersquove been blown away in the past number of weeks with the support from customers visiting us there. This means so much to us in such challenging times.".

Will the Prime Minister confirm that the introduction of any airbridges will be based on public health assessments, not economic assessments and can you also confirm that the devolved governments will be closely involved and party to any arrangements with any country on the arrangements "Mr Johnson replied: " AsI said in my statement, I observe that the harmony between all four nations is running closer than you might sometimes believe from listening to the Right Honourable gentleman, but I agreed with a great deal of what he had to say. "Hes right to express the caution that he does, hes right to anticipate the risk of second spikes...Imust be absolutely clear about that, we will see future outbreaks and we will be in a much better position now to control those outbreaks."He added: "I will, of course, publishedthe measures on social distancing, how the decision was reached on social distance, well place that in both libraries of bothhouses."On airbridges, which would allow quarantine-free travel between UK citizens and those of the partnering country, Mr Johnson said: "We will ensure that of course the devolved administrations are kept in contactas we develop our plans, and our plansfor quarantine will be basedentirely, as he rightly suggests, on public health."That will be our criteria."

title: tourism-businesses-economically-unsustainable-2m-distancing-rule
story: Focusing on the hospitality sector, the Scottish Tourism Alliance found the vast majority of firms will struggle under the m measure.In the survey of , businesses including hotels, restaurants and cafes from June  to June , some  per centsaid they will have to stop tradingthe rule remains in place and no further financial help is offered.The Scottish Beer  Pub Association ran a similar survey during the same time period, which found just % of pubs believe they can reopen with m social distancing measures.Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday that the regulation will be relaxed to m-plus from July  in England, with people advised to take other precautions such as wearing face coverings.Nicola Sturgeon saidthe Scottish Government has asked its scientic advisory group to review the measure. It is expected to report by July .Marc Crothall, chief executive of the Scottish Tourism Alliance, said: "The survey confirms that around % of businesses within the hotel and restaurant sectors in Scotland will stop tradingthe m physical distancing rule remains in place for the next two months should no further financial support be forthcoming."The figures reflect the many conversations we have been having with businesses across all sectors in the tourism industry for months and underline just how crucial the current review of the m physical distancing rule is within the context of the health and economic crises."Almost a third of hotels surveyed said they will not reopen on July  directly because of the social distancing regulations, while % of restaurants said they cannot afford to continuerestrictions are not reduced to m.Restaurants saidthey are required to trade at m without any additional support beyond the next two months, there will be almost , jobs at risk due to closures.Mr Crothall said: "Our tourism industry has welcomed the publication of the sector guidance for reopening and fully supports all recommended measures to ensure the safety of employees, visitors and our communities."However, many businesses do not plan to open again with the m rule in place as its simply not economically viable for them to do so."Coupled with the expected slow recovery forecast, we expect a steady stream of job losses across the whole of Scotland over the coming weeks."He added: "Also, as we all know, visitors will choose where to stay based on the tourism product available in that area and are unlikely to travel to destinations that have a limited product in the form of restaurants, visitor attractions and pubs."This will have a direct knock-on effect on the current limited demand for accommodation in our destinations and the impact on our local economies and supply chain is likely to be severe."

story: A spokesman for Downing Street said the conferences will now only be made to "coincide with signicant announcements, including with the PM"It comes after Boris Johnson announced a plan to ease lockdown in England, including reducing the m social distancing rule to "m plus" - meaningresidents in Englandcan be within one metre of one another provided they take precautionssuch as mask-wearing.The data from the daily briefings, including infection rates, deaths and hospitalisations as well as testing figures, will still be published online Monday to Friday."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Boris Johnson announces changes to social distancing guidelines in England","description": "Boris Johnson announces changes to social distancing guidelines in England","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media RISWVjF poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests RISWVjF.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The spokesman said: " From today, the press conference will no longer be daily.
